rabbit
Homonym Number:  3
Word Class: verb
Sense Number:
Definition: to steal surreptitiously (esp. potatoes by digging out potato tubers, leaving the tops still growing; BANDICOOT; MILK) (cf RABBIT n. for poss. derivation; phs f. general idea of rabbits' burrowing for tubes or perhaps from a stock answer to enquiry `Where's my potatoes?', `The rabbits have got them.' But rabbits would usually eat tops and leave tubers.)
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: ca1930 Nelson potatoes -->ca1952 Wellington potatoes
Citations

Source:  Men of God
Author:  GLOVER
Vol / Page:  10
Edition:
Quote:  On the way out at the gate Joe [an ex-convict] hesitated then said to himself, No, it wouldn't be fair to rabbit the old codger's letterbox.
Notes:

Date:  18/11/1933
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  15
Edition:
Quote:  Rabbit dogs.- Those spoken of such include greyhounds, lurchers, spaniels, and nondescript terriers; sometimes retrievers. They were  called the r. pack and in the `nineties some station r.ps. had as many as 30 dogs in them. If one of them retrieved he was called a carrier and sometimes rabbiters point out a dog as a great nester (smeller out of r. nests). (C.)

Quote:  Swing Gates. - Swing gates or rabbit-proof gates can be put up across roads and bridges with the consent of the local authority; they can remain only during that authority's pleasure. They must be properly hung, and provided with an efficient fastening capable of being opened by a person on horseback.

rabbit-sick
Homonym Number:
Word Class: adjective
Sense Number:

race
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: [stockyards] a passage through which stock pass single file in drafting, or into dips or showers, or the passage through which dairy cows pass entering or leaving a cowshed.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:

Date:  13/3/1883
Source:  Hawera & Normanby Star
Author:

Vol / Page:  2
Edition:
Quote:  I have fixed up a bail at the end of the race, or crush pen. One side of the race at the bail is formed by a strong gate, which is opened when the cow is bailed for milking. So soon as the cow has entered the race a bar is slipped in behind her across the race, and another bar is slipped across behind her when close up to the bail.

Notes:

raddle
Homonym Number:
Word Class: verb
Sense Number:
Definition: to rob (esp. be raddled)
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1989
Source:  NZ English Newsletter
Author:
Vol / Page:  3/26-27
Edition:
Quote:  raddled: This word means `robbed' in the sense of being deprived of one's proper payment. It is an extension of `raddling', carried out by unscrupulous farmers before the Shearers' Union looked after shearers' interests. Any sheep considered unsatisfactorily shorn was marked with red or blue raddle and such a sheep would not be counted in the shearer's

tally. The raddle stick was also called a `Toby'. This must not be confused with [27] marking a sheep for other purposes, such as identification of certain sheep for easy selection later.


Notes:  (Wallace Shearing Glossary)

raddle
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:

raddle money
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: a deduction made to a shearer’s pay for sheep that are cut during shearing [such sheep being marked with raddle.]

raddle money
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: (shearers')
Citations
Date:  0/0/1960
Source:  Sheep-O
Author:  MILLS
Vol / Page:  122
Edition:
Quote:  This [South Island] shed is often said ... to have been paid for with `raddle money', a term that many of our younger shearers have never even heard. In those days ... a shearer had to shear cleanly, or have many of his sheep heavily marked in the count-out pens and excluded from his tally. Inevitably the boss stood to benefit from such a one-sided bargain, hence the term, raddle money.

Date:  27/1/1934
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  15
Edition:
Quote:  Raddling.-An old-time shed practice, whereby the shed boss put a raddle-mark on any sheep in the counting-out pen not shorn to his satisfaction, and the shearer was not paid for it. Old hands often spoke of this practice. I think the great shearers' strike at the beginning of the 'nineties

ended it.

Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Jim Cameron writes: In the sense of a radiant electric heater, Collins records this as <i>Austral & NZ</i>. This was the ordinary NZ term for this object at least up to the 1960s. A notice published in the press in 3/00 mentions <i>electric radiator</i>. Not in DNZE or NZPOD Also often called <i>bar heater</I>.

rafter

Sense Number:

Date:  0/0/1894
Source:  NZ Official Yearbook
Author:
Vol / Page:  365
Edition:
Quote:  At the mouths of streams a line of floating [kauri] logs have been previously fastened together with iron `dogs' and short chains; this is called a `boom', and

prevents the timber getting away to sea. The logs are then fastened together in rafts, and, guided by men armed with long poles shod with iron (called rafting-spears), are conveyed to the mills, ...


Notes:   (E. Tregear: Labour in NZ)

Quote:  Rah! A coll. abbr. of hurrah!: orig. and mainly U.S.,  anglicised ca. 1910. N.b., rah! (shouted thrice) forms the termination of the Maori war-cry, now-and since late C. 19-affected by Maori and other New Zealand Rugby teams ca1940 A Campbell: especially in the bastard, non-Maori hakas down South (Dunedin, Otago, Canterbury), but not heard much up North.  (but cf Boomeranga.)  WF interj since ca1875.

Notes:

Date:  2/11/1850
Source:  New Zealander, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  3
Edition:
Quote:  The natives always treat a rahui with much respect, considering it an act of great dishonesty to catch eels, or any other fish, to hunt pigs, snare ducks or parrots, or in fact destroy in any way or [sic] game of whatever kind which it is erected to preserve. So strictly is this code carried out, that a short time ago - (and even now in some parts of the island) the infringement of a rahui would be considered quite a sufficient <i>casus belli</i> to give rise to a bloody war between two tribes.
Notes:

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Austral English
Author:  MORRIS
Vol / Page:  378
Edition:
Quote:  Rail, n. common English bird-name. There are many varieties in New Zealand and Australia, especially in the former colony, and the authorities differ as to whether some should be classed as distinct species. Some are common to Australasia, others endemic in New Zealand or Australia; their distribution in this respect is marked below in parentheses. Several species receive more than one vernacular name, as the the following list shows - Banded Rail (N.Z. and A.)- <i>Rallus philippensis</i>,Linn. ...  Dieffenbach's R. (...) <i>Rallus dieffenbachii</i>, Gray.  Hutton's R. (N.Z.)- <i>Cabalus modestus</i>, Hutton.  Land R. (N.Z. and A.)- <i>Rallus philippensis</i>, Linn. ...  Swamp R. (Australasia)- <i>Ortygometra tabuensis</i>, Finsch. ... Weka R. (N.Z. see Weka) see also <i>Takahe and Notornis</i>.

Vol / Page:  217
Edition:
Quote:  The railers flocked to it. These are so-called fishermen whose greed for fish far outruns their angling skill. They are a pest likely to be encountered on many Taupo waters. They stand in a swift current, peel off the whole length of a dressed line and let it float down the stream, generally with 40 or 50 yds. of backing as well. Then they fish the [218] fly on the reel. It is illegal under the Taupo fishing regulations, but it is a practice which the rangers cannot easily detect or suppress.

rainbird

See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1904
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  36/134
Edition:
Quote:  Like the Cuckoos in other parts of the world, they appear before rainy weather or coincident with it, and have thus come to be known in many widely different localities as `Rain-birds' and `Storm-birds'. In many parts of Otago and Canterbury they were called by the early settlers `Potato-birds', as they invariably came on the scene as the potato-planting was going on; similarly, in the North Island they got the name of `Kumara-birds'.

Vol / Page:  120
Edition:
Quote:  RAINBOW CAKE... Divide mixture into 3 parts. Flavour 1st with teaspoon grated lemon rind., Flavour 2nd with teaspoon orange rind, and colour pink with cochineal... Add to the 3rd 1 dessertspoon cocoa... Bake about hour in 3 sponge sandwich tins... Fasten together with lemon honey, and ice all over with chocolate icing.

rainforest
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: woodland in a mild climate with heavy rainfall, typically having many tree varieties but dominated by one, e.g. in New Zealand often by podocarps. Also called temperate rain forest.

rakkyo
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a small Japanese onion
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  25/5/2002
Source:  Dominion
Author:
Vol / Page:  7
Edition:
Quote:  A new vegetable said to be ideal for stir-frys, curries and salads is ready for planting and could be in the shops in time for Christmas dinner. It is a small onion, described by Crop and Food Research scientists who developed it as a cross between shallots and chives. Its taste is mild, somewhere between garlic and onion, and it is crisp in texture. Known in Japan as rakkyo and used in a popular pickle called tsukemono,it was brought to New Zealand in 1997 to be tested as a commercial vegetable.

ramarama
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a shrub or small tree, Lophomyrtus bullata, of coastal and lowland forest, having shiny blistered leaves (more common in the North Island).
Origin: Maori
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: [1919 July 29] Ver.(WB). = Vernacular names used by settlers supplied by W.Best, Otaki (And) <i>Myrtus bullata</i> rum-a-rum

ramp
Homonym Number:
Word Class: verb
Sense Number:
Definition: to leave, clear out
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: (criminals')
Citations
Date:  0/0/1879
Source:  Spangles and Sawdust
Author:  WHITWORTH
Vol / Page:  5
Edition:
Quote:  I was down there with Old Ashmore's lot, doing the trampoline, and so on; but things was very quizby. Everything went crooked somehow, and the gorger had a hawful cramp in his kick. Well, ramp was the word, and vamose we did, the lot on us; some here, some there. I was reg'lar beached, and I tell you when a cove 'as to spout his smish it's about time to look out. However, I got a job at a livery stable, but although that kep' me in grub, and I slep' in a spare stall, the billet was very multy, and I kep' on the kivvy for something better. [fn] 1. [trampoline] Vaulter. 2. [quizby] Bad. 3. [crooked] Wrong. 4. [cramp in his kick] Emptiness in his pockets. 5. [ramp] Clear out. 6. [vamose] Go. 7. [beached] Hard up. 8. [smish] Shirt. 9. [multy] No good. 10. [kivvy] Look out (qui vive.)

rangatira
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a chief or noble person
Origin: Maori
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Commonly used by English speakers for people of public or private importance or mana

Date:  0/0/1817
Source:  New Zealand (various authors/titles)
Author:  NICHOLAS
Vol / Page:  1/91
Edition:
Quote:  Duaterra immediately recognised [the chief], and ... behaved to him with particular respect, touching noses with him, the usual mode of salutation in this part of the world, when any honour is to be paid, and which he did not do with the other chief. The latter he contemptuously described as an ittee ittee rungateeda, or a chief possessing very little power. <i>Ibid.</I> 1/227

He assisted us ... but reflecting at intervals on the rank he held among his countrymen, which was that of a  rungateeda, or gentleman, he would several times shake his head, and cry out against this indignity, ... <i>Ibid.</i> 1/292 All the males belonging to the family of the chief are styled  rungateedas, and these have generally servants of their own to wait upon them. <i>Ibid.</i> 2/339 A gentleman Rungateeda

was more or less a "rangatira."

rangatira girl
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a high-born young Maori woman
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:

Notes: ? a coinage of Miller's in 1958 Miller Early Victorian NZ 141 or does it echo or copy an original in Chapman

Citations
Date:  24/11/1847
Source:  Letter
Author:  H.S. CHAPMAN
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:   [quotation marks enclose Chapman's original] Unable to bear the solitary life, not a few acquired `Maori wives', which was `the conventional name for a Maori mistress'. The native women often welcomed the squatters with bouquets of flowers and became very attached to their young men. The high-born Rangitira girls were sometimes richly beautiful, displaying a lithe elastic figure, soft brilliant eyes and rose brown complexions, set off by glossy black hair falling to the knees.


Notes:  1847 Nov 24 H.S. Chapman letters to His Father [TS, ATB] in 1958 Miller Early Victorian NZ 141



Date:  0/0/1958
Source:  Early Victorian NZ
Author:  MILLER
Vol / Page:  141
Edition:
Quote:  :cf MAORI WIFE]  The native women often welcome the squatters with bouquets of flowers and became very attached to their young men. The high-born Rangitira girls were sometimes richly beautiful ... <I>Ibid.</I> 166 Always quick to imitate new fashions, the young Maoris would turn out for their own flat and hurdle races attired in true jockey style ...; while the attractive Rangatira girls also took to the saddle, equipped with gauntlets and silver whip, habit, hat and plume.
Notes:  [possibly reflecting Chapman Letter 24 Nov 1847; with cap: is this Miller or reflects Bell in Stafford Papers 21/12/1851]

Date:  4/9/2003

Vol / Page:  B5

Quote:  Rangatiratanga is a collective concept. You can't sell your rangatiratanga. In the Treaty of Waitangi, the word "rangatiratanga" appears in article 2. It is translated as "ownership" in the English version. Maori are guaranteed their rangatiratanga over lands, forests and fisheries.

Quote:  Some time before we came to Taupo a handsome `Pataka' (viz. a Maori store for food) had been burned. Sir George Grey when on his visit to Taupo saw the said Pataka and told Te Heuheu (no doubt in a jocose way) that it was a sign of his `Rangatiratanga.'
Notes:  1858 Mar 24 T.S.Grace letter in Grace Pioneer Missionary (1928) 76



Date:  0/0/1986
Source:  NZ Wars, The
Author:  BELICH
Vol / Page:  337
Edition:
Quote:  rangatiratanga sphere, authority, of the chiefs


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1989
Source:  Principles for Crown Action
Author:
Vol / Page:  7
Edition:
Quote:  The Principle of Self-Management The Rangatiratanga Principle The iwi have the right to organise as iwi, and, under the law, to control their re
Sources as their own. <i>Ibid.</i> 11

The New Zealand Maori Council has explained the concept of Rangatiratanga as meaning more

than `possession':  `it means the wise administration of all the assets possessed by a group for that group's benefit: in a word, trusteeship'  (Te Wahanga Tuatahi, 1983, p 5)  In the Crown's view, the First and Second Articles of the Treaty are both strong statements which necessarily

qualify one another. Kawanatanga is subject to a promise to protect  Rangatiratanga. Rangatiratanga is subject to an acknowledgment of Kawanatanga. The working out in practice of the balance between the two Articles must depend upon a case by case consideration. ... It is the right of all citizens, Maori, Pakeha, and other New Zealanders, that there be effective Government or Kawanatanga in such matters.


Notes:

Date:  19/11/1988
Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page:  16
Edition:
Quote:  More insidiously, the actual terms of the treaty such as "rangatiratanga" and "full and exclusive possession" are being redefined to proscribe Maori rights.

Vol / Page:  4
Edition:
Quote:  That on and after November 1 the Ranger be instructed not to impound cattle, sheep, or horses, grazing on roads within the Otangaki, Hiwinui, Taonui, Makino, Raumanga, and Mangaone ridings, between the hours of 7 a.m. and 5 p.m.; this, however, not to apply to entire animals nor swine; rangers are instructed to inform the county solicitor of cases of swine and entire animals grazing on roads, and the owners to be prosecuted; the rangers are further instructed to impound at all hours animals wandering on the river beds and so destroying the settlers' protective work.

Quote:  He has had a rough time of it surveying a block on the ranges up the Wai-o-hine in the Wairarapa ...[sic] Once ...[sic] they had nothing to eat but a tui and a more-pork. ... They were stewing the two birds when a kuku-pa (bush pigeon) flew up and perched. Bob shot it ... This is not exactly what the Britishers call `sport' - but there is more of nature about it than 30 gents in pink and tops ... waiting for a wretched little fox who, when he is

killed, is not equal for culinary purposes to a more-pork. Once coming up the Waikato in 1851 your Uncle James got a pot-shot at a lot of parera (grey duck) ...


Notes:  (C.W. Richmond)

Vol / Page:  87
Edition:  1970
Quote:  ... such species as lancewood, karamu, toro, ramarama, koromiko, kanono, kohuhu, kawakawa, hangehange, rangiora, five finger, patete, toru, tree daisies, broadleaf, kamahi, mahoe, tarata, karo, lacebark, wineberry, fuchsia, kowhai, with tree ferns, weki, and mamuku. Toetoe, phormium, cabbage tree, with swamp coprosma and hupiro may figure as a developmental phase on wet soils.

<I>C. robusta</I> and <I>C. lucida</I>, the bubbly-leaved  ramarama (<I>Lophomyrtus bullata</I>), wharangi  (<I>Melicope ternata</I>), the `tree daisies' heketara  (<I>Olearia rani</I>) and the familiar large-leaved rangiora (<I>Brachyglottis repanda</I>).

Rangitata skink
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a skink discovered in 2004,  resident only on Mt Harper in the Rangitata gorge; closely related to and coexisting, but not interbreeding, with the Long-toed skink.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Environment
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: <i>Oligosoma "Rangitata"</i>

Vol / Page:  83
Edition:
Quote:  This skink is known from a single mountain, but unless specimens are examined up close they are easily mistaken for the much commoner McCann's skink, so Rangitata skinks could well have been overlooked at other localities.

Rangitawa pumice
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: Geol. defn
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/11/1988
Source:  Geological Society of NZ Newsletter
Author:
Vol / Page:  82/36
Edition:
Quote:  Another widespread silicic airfall tephra reported from southern North Island is the Rangitawa Pumice and its possible correlatives, the Omahina Tephra (Pillans 1979), the Lower Finnie Road Ash (Seward 1974 ; Pillans & Kohn 1981), and the Mangaroa Ash (Neeser et al. 1980), all with fission-track dates in the two-standard deviation age range of 370 ± 70 ky BP (Pillans & Kohn 1981; Kyle & Seward 1984; Kohl 1986, oral presentation).  The site 594 tephra could therefore be equivalent to the Rangitawa Pumice and its correlatives.
Notes:

Rangitoto
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: the iconic Auckland Harbour island volcano
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/7/2004
Source:  NZ Geographic

Author:
Vol / Page:  No. 68/21
Edition:
Quote:  From the air, Rangitoto's 258 m high sunmmit looks more like a green poached egg than a rugged volcanic cone. Molten lava spewed from around the crater as recently as 600 years ago and plenty of raw rock is still visible between the clumps of encroaching trees. While the eruptions left Rangitoto with a black and scaly skin, ash deposited on neighbouring Motutapu Island.. smoothed the topography and endowed it with up to two metres of rich topsoil. <i><Ibid.</i> 24 ...[Tamatekapua's] fate endures in the island's full name - "Te Rangi I Totongia A Tametakapua" or "the day the blood of Tametekapua was shed"... The early eruptions of Rangitoto were the most ferocious, driven by seawater flashing steam as it encountered fresh magma at 1200 degrees C.
Notes:

Notes:  Submitted by David More

Date:  0/0/1985
Source:  G'day Country
Author:  McGILL
Vol / Page:  49
Edition:
Quote:  It seemed downright peculiar to be leaving what Dad called Auckland's `dolsi vita' ... `Do you

know what they call us in Wellington?' Dad asked on the way. `What?' `Rangitoto Yankees.' I had never heard it, but I figured it was a small price, ... to pay for what Dad reckons is Paradise.

<I>Ibid.</I> 171 `I miss that underground mutton.' `Eh?' `Rabbit. You are back in 10 minutes with your supper.' ... We need an Eric Partridge to record these Kiwi colloquialisms like underground mutton, Rangitoto Yankees, leather ladies (possums hit by trains in tunnels, where the flies don't get to them and they petrify) and the Waiouru blondes (sheep).

rap jump
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  11/5/1997
Source:  Sunday Times (UK)
Author:
Vol / Page:  6.5
Edition:
Quote:  Kiwis have this thing about vertical rubber experiences. They can't wait to leap from bridges with an elastic band on their feet, fling themselves from aircraft with pros strapped to their back like copulating dragonflies, jump into underground rivers with rubber rings around their middles, "rap jump" - abseil down the outer walls of hgih-rise buildings - and "zorb", roll down hills inside transparent rubber spheres... Even tiny Takaka not only has bungee jumping but serious "swinging", the latest in fear fads involving a 60 mph, 50 yd flight over an abyss.

Date:  0/0/1881

Author:  NESFIELD
Vol / Page:  38
Edition:
Quote:  Although, there were plenty of station horses, ... I invested in a couple for my own private use. ... [One] bucked me off more times than I can remember, and I began to get `full' of him. George, my mate, proposed Rarey-fying him. The process consisted in breathing up his nose ... One of

Rarey's theories was that the breath of man inhaled into the horse's nostrils intimidated him.

Edition:
Quote:  The <i>Rari</i> , a fish often found eight feet long, the body is large and tapers suddenly into a arrow tail, which is surrounded by a fin above and below, as that of the eel, without having any separate caudal one, the eye is large, the upper part of the head and back covered with spots, the lips are thick, from the lower one are four barbules, the fins red.

Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  35/319
Edition:
Quote:  Mair Fish in Piako River ... <i>large numbers of aua or kataha</i> (Agonostoma forsteri); <i>about 60 lb. ... weight of pilchard or mohimohi  (Clupea sagax)</i>, two varieties; ... hundreds of young  red-cod, rarii (<i>Lotella bacchus</i>), and what I believe are  young rock-cod, or kokopu or rawaru (<i>Percis colias</i>). The red-cod were from 3 in. to 4 in. in length, and the rawaru, or, as the natives here call them, `toitoi' or `panepane', from 2 in. to 6 in. long.

Vol / Page:

Quote:  They're middle-aged and sensible, long disillusioned with the sanctity of marriage, and the vice that really rarks them up is smoking.


Notes:

Date:  22/4/2000
Source:  Dominion
Author:
Vol / Page:  20
Edition:
Quote:  Some accept the meaning I use : to infuriate someone by teasing, to the amusement of those in the know. But for one who agrees, three or four insist <i>rark</i> refers to a justified telling-off. Ted Anderson writes to say he grew up in Nelson and his wife Anne in Thames, and the pair of them have always used <i>rark</i> to mean stirring one up when they deserve it... Donald Macintosh Campbell... ferreted out Fr P S Dineen's <i>Dictionary of the Irish Language</i> which gives <i>radharc mo shul do bhaite</i>, meaning essentially "to fool me" and shortened to <i>radharc</i>. Since the letters <i>dh</i> in the middle of <i>radharc</i> are silent, like the <i>gh</i> in night, the pronunciation was <i>rarc</i>. Either way, it's fun to be rarked up.

Quote:  The Royal Agricultural Society of New Zealand (RAS) promotes the development of agricultural, pastoral, horticultural, stock-raising and forestry re
Sources in New Zealand. ... The RAS of NZ is a member of the Royal Agricultural Society of the Commonwealth, which offers benefits to life members attending overseas Royal Shows. ... While the RAS was instigated at a time in New Zealand when farming and related activities were considered to be the dominant way of life, it is an organisation that is still very relevant today.

Date:  29/1/1908
Source:  Otago Witness
Author:
Vol / Page:  15
Edition:
Quote:  The Maori rat, as I know it, is rather smaller than the common or Norwegian variety. It has a very long tail - at least one third longer than the ordinary; - its coat is as fine as velvet, and is of a bluish colour, showing at first sight a black shade, while the head is also a more pleasing type.
Notes:

Date:  29/10/1769
Source:  Cook's Journals
Author:
Vol / Page:  1/186
Edition:  1955
Quote:  We saw no four footed Animals either tame or wild or signs of any except Dogs and Ratts and these were very scarce especialy the latter. [f@n1] ... The so-called Native Rat or kiore, thought to be identical with <i>Rattus exulans</i> of Fiji is now almost extinct.
Notes:

Date:  31/3/1770
Source:  Cook's Journals
Author:
Vol / Page:  1/277
Edition:  1955
Quote:  The country is certainly destitute of all sorts of beasts either wild or tame except Dogs and Ratts, [sic] the former are tame and live with the people who breed and bring them up for no other purpose than to eat and ratts are so scare that not only I but many others in the ship never saw one.


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1835
Source:  Boultbee Journal
Author:
Vol / Page:  110
Edition:  1986
Quote:  rat - kior|ee [kiore]


Notes:  >c1826-1827 list of Maori words in c1835 Boultbee Journal (1986) 110; also 1826-28 Boultbee Vocabulary in 1979 Begg 283 (|= macron precedes) rat, kio|re [kiore]

Date:  0/0/1851
Source:  Papers & Proc. RS Van Diemen's Land
Author:
Vol / Page:  1/301
Edition:
Quote:  The Secretary read the following extracts from a letter of the Rev. W. Colenso to Ronald C. Gunn, Esq., of Launceston, dated Waitangi, Hawke's Bay, New Zealand, 4th September, 1850:- `I have procured two specimens of the ancient, and all but quite extinct, New Zealand Rat, which until just now (and notwithstanding all my endeavours, backed, too,

by large rewards) I never saw. It is without doubt a true Mus, smaller than our English black rat (Mus Rattus), and not unlike it. This little animal once inhabited the plains and Fagus forests of New Zealand in countless thousands, and was both the common food and great delicacy of the natives - and already it is all but quite classed among the things which were.'


Notes:   [Morris]

Date:  0/0/1880

Edition:
Quote:  <i>Metrosideros lucida</i>, Menzies. Rata, Ironwood.--A very ornamental tree; attains a height of 30-60 feet, and a diameter of 2-10 feet. The timber of this tree forms a valuable cabinet wood;

Grows rarely in the North Island, but is abundant in the South Island

Notes:

rata
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a) a large native forest tree with bright red flowers. b) a lofty-climbing forest vine. [Maori rata[a's-macron]]
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: for Metrosideros spp. for tree-forms, and occas. for the liane see also IRONWOOD, RATA-VINE
Pronunciation:
Notes: General, largely unspecified rata.  or with descriptive epithet <i>Metrosideros robusta </i>(formerly <i>M. florida</i> Hook.f.; usu. RATA or NORTHERN RATA and <i>M. umbellata</i> (usu. SOUTHERN RATA, and prob. dominant on w. coast of S.I.) forest trees, as distinct from the lianes (usu. AKA q.v.) <i>M. scandens</i> (formerly <i>M. perforata</i>), <i>M. albiflora</i> (?often WHITE RATA and formerly <i>M. diffusa</i> A.Cunn.) and <i>M. diffusa</i> Forst. f.  (formerly <i>M. hypericifolia</i> A.Cunn.)  named RATA in Maori as distinct from AKA, the RATA-VINE  (<i>M. scandens</i>), see CLIMBING RATA, CLINGING RATA 3. below  plural <i>ratas, rata </i>
Citations
Date:  0/0/1841
Source:  NZ Journal
Author:
Vol / Page:  51
Edition:
Quote:  rata : sometimes you meet with a rata, which here is one of the highest in New Zealand...
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1907
Source:  Plants of NZ
Author:  LAING & BLACKWELL
Vol / Page:  278
Edition:  1940 p. 292
Quote:  <I>Genus Metrosideros</I> ... (Name from the Greek,  meaning <I>iron-hearted</I>, in allusion to the iron-like hardness of the timber). Plants of the genus are usually known to the colonists

[bushmen] by the Maori name <i>Rata</i>. 12 sp. Williams 327 <i>Ra[a]ta[a] ... 1. Metrodiseros robusta</i>, a forest tree. ... 2. <i>Metrosideros excela</i>, locally south of East Cape. ... = po[o]hutukawa.:

early spg <i>lahtah, rattar </i>

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1840
Source:  Manners & Customs of the NZers
Author:  POLACK
Vol / Page:  1/70
Edition:
Quote:  In 1835, an influential priest was bribed by us to dispose of an ancient adze, called

toki pu tangata[a2-acute] by the people; it was extremely ancient, and had been buried in a sandy soil for many years; the place of its interment was only known to the priest, who had noted the spot by the branching of a [71] particular tree called  Rata[as-acute]... 1/71 fn The adze was formed of a blue granite inserted in a handle of the rata or red pine-wood, carved agreeably to native taste.

Date:  0/0/1848
Source:  Handbook for New Zealand, The
Author:  WAKEFIELD
Vol / Page:  142
Edition:
Quote:  10. Rata, (<i>Metrosideros robusta</i>.) There are several varieties of this tree; one grows at first as a parasite, creeping in numerous stems, like ropes, up the trunks of the other forest trees, gradually enclosing them till they perish, and then uniting to form a noble tree taller than that which it has destroyed, with an enormous trunk, but hollow within.

Notes:  1886 T.Kirk in 1902 Settler's Handbook of NZ 121

Date:  0/0/1889
Source:  Art Album NZ Flora
Author:  FEATON
Vol / Page:  158
Edition:
Quote:  METROSIDEROS FLORIDA (<i>Smith</i>). ... This beautiful species is a lofty climber in all stages of its existence, ... It is commonly called `Rata' and is often confounded with its ally, M. robusta, the Rata proper; ... <i>Ibid.</i> 161 METROSIDEROS ROBUSTA (<i>A.Cunn.</i>) ... The `RATA'.- This beautiful ... tree is almost confined to the Northern Island ... It is generally affirmed that the plant is a climber, ... [162] The tree is sometimes though improperly designated the `Female Pohutukawa'.


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1889
Source:  Catalogue NZ Exhibition
Author:
Vol / Page:  35
Edition:
Quote:  English Name Native name Botanical Name Rata Rata Metrosideros Lucida
Notes:  1889 Canterbury [Catalogue Canterbury Court, Exhibition) 35

Date:  0/0/1889
Source:  Forest Flora
Author:  KIRK
Vol / Page:  263
Edition:
Quote:  It is invariably erect and never climbing, although bushmen and settlers frequently state that it climbs the loftiest trees, and sooner or later squeezes them to death in its iron clasp. In proof of this they assert that, when felling huge ratas, they often find a dead tree in the centre of the rata: this is a common occurrence, but it by no means follows that this species is a climber. The error is simply due to imperfect observation, which has led careless observers to confuse [<I>M. scandens</I> the Aka], which is a true climber with <I>M. robusta</I>.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Austral English
Author:  MORRIS
Vol / Page:  380
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Rata, n.</i> Maori name for two New Zealand erect or sub-scandent flowering trees, often embracing trunks of forest trees and strangling them: the Northern Rata, <i> Metrosideros robusta </i> , A. Cunn., and the Southern Rata, <i> M. lucida </i> , Menz., both of the N.O. <i> Myrtacea </i> . The tree called by the Maoris Aka, which is another species of <i> Metrosideros (M. florida)</i> , is also often confused with the Rata by bushmen and settlers. In Maori, the adj. <i> rata </i>  means red-hot, and there may be a reference to the scarlet appearance of the flower in full bloom. The timber of the Rata is often known as <i> Ironwood </i> , or <i> Ironbark </i> . The trees rise to sixty feet in height; they generally begin by trailing downwards from the seed deposited on the bark of some other tree near its top. When the trailing branches reach the ground they take root there and sprout erect. For full account of the habit of the trees, see quotation 1867 (Hochstetter), 1879 (Moseley), and 1889 (Kirk).


Notes:

Date:  10/11/1892

Vol / Page:

Quote:  <i> ra[a]ta[a],</i>  a tree (Metrosideros spp.), crimson flower that covers the trees with sheets of

colour: it may start in a fork of any tree, and sends down rootlets that grow in size till they surround the [146] tree and strangle it, when the rata stands on its own. Rata (no macrons) has quite other meanings.

Author:  BOSWELL
Vol / Page:  101
Edition:
Quote:   ... I recall his [the botanist-Inspector's] chuckle when we showed him ... the huge white caterpillar known throughout bushland [in North Auckland] as the `rata grub', so-called because it was always found at the foot of a rata and was supposed to be the origin [101] of the tree itself. It is a curious creature - a great caterpillar with a strange tree-like fungoid growth, growing sometimes to a height of several inches, from its body. I think everybody believed in the legend of the rata-tree caterpillar; ...

ratbag
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: OED: Austral. and N.Z. slang. A stupid or eccentric person, a fool; an unpleasant person, a trouble-maker. Also attrib., stupid, idiotic,

uncouth.


Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: ca1951 R.Gilberd (Okaihau) `a common derogatory term suggesting that (1) a man is worthless or (2) he falls short of his pretence, i.e. is a humbug.' 1984 17 M E99 Pakuranga Coll. 3  RATBAG

Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  On December 24, 1866, the diarist remarks: `Sent rations to Stotburn hut.' I understand `rations' was the common term, although I did not see its use elsewhere in the diary, the word stores being used quite a few times. On May 20, 1867, we note that `J. Gavin drove to Drysdale's with provisions' - the solitary use of this word.
Notes:  1866 Dec 24 Puketoi Station Diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 115

Date:  18/11/1933
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  15
Edition:
Quote:  Rations.-. Pronounced to rhyme with `nations', not with `passions' as in the army. The r. system went out of general use in Canterbury in the 'seventies. The old scale was 16lb meat, 10lb flour, 2lb sugar, l/4 lb tea a man a week; or sometimes 12lb meat, 12lb flour, 2lb sugar, and

1/4 lb tea. (C.)


Notes:  Acland Glossary

Date:  0/0/1947
Source:  Early Runholding in Otago
Author:  BEATTIE
Vol / Page:  12
Edition:
Quote:  A pioneer told me that a bullock team ... might cart in `provisions' or `supplies' for a station, but the provisions became `rations' (which he pronounced `rayshuns') when served out to the men at the `shepherd's huts' (or out-stations), and these rations became `tucker' when apportioned as meals. ... Another pioneer, in referring to the food the men got on the stations, said it was called by the ship term `rations' (which he pronounced `rashuns')

Wellington: Who Goes Round My Stone Wall, Beg o' My Neighbor, Bellahonie, Run a Mile, On and Off the Bridge, Here Come Two Nuns, Colours, Isaac and Rebecca. Canterbury: Poor Old Tom, Rats and Rabbits and Rips, Steps, Skin the Snake, Steal a Peg, Toodle-em-Buck, The Gag;  Golden Bay: Who's That Walking Round My House Tonight, I've Come to See Poor Mary Jane, Steps and Stairs, Creeping, Branding, O'Leary;  Otago: Sir Roger de Coverley, Who's That Knocking at My Door.

ratstail
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: broad-leaved plantain
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1926
Source:  Weeds of New Zealand
Author:  HILGENDORF
Vol / Page:  161
Edition:  1967
Quote:  BROAD-LEAVED PLANTAIN (<i>Plantago major</i>), also called ratstail, birdseed, lamb's tongue, and greater plantain, is common on roadsides and trodden places throughout the country

and in pastures in the King Country. ... From the middle of the rosette ascends the flower stalk ... , which afterwards give[s] place to seeds, and produce[s] the ratstail appearance that gives the plant one of its trivial names. The long spikes of seed pods are often used for feeding caged birds.

Author:
Vol / Page:  3
Edition:
Quote:  The flower, stem, and leaves, enclosed in the above letter when I received it, were those of the sporobolus elongatus, in some districts called "ratstail grass," in others "Chilian grass," and probably a dozen or two local names, for all I know to the contrary. It is a native of the province of Auckland, and of late years has been spreading rapidly, in consequence of the extension of agriculture.

Vol / Page:  156
Edition:  1984
Quote:  RATTAILS: <i> Macrouridae</i>  The fishes in this family are collectively known as rattails, a name suggested by the greatly elongated pointed tail. Other names commonly applied to this group are whiptails and grenadiers. ... About 25 species are found around New Zealand ...


Notes:

Date:  22/7/1988
Source:  Evening Post
Author:
Vol / Page:  14/9
Edition:
Quote:  The fish, known as the `rattail' or Coelinchorus, were caught off the coast of ... Taranaki, in the orange roughy grounds at a depth of 800m ... The rattail also known as the grenadier is closely related to the codfish family, feeding on the bottom of the ocean ... Of the 40 known species of

Coelinchorus 11 of them seem to be indigenous only to New Zealand says Mr Pauling.

Author:  SORENSON
Vol / Page:  29
Edition:
Quote:  HAKE, BLUE  (a) Scientific name: <i> Macruronus novaezealandiae</i> . (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Blue Hake. (c) Other common names: Whiptail; Rat-tail. (d) Principal localities where taken: Wellington, Nelson, Southern New Zealand.


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1986
Source:  NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author:  PAUL
Vol / Page:  62
Edition:
Quote:  <i> Grenadiers or rattails</i>  A family (Macrouridae) of deepwater fishes, characterised by a large head, short body, and long tapering tail. The last feature gives rise to their alternative common name of rattail, the name most commonly used in New Zealand.

Quote:  <I> Linum monogynum (The True New Zealand Flax)</i> ... Native name Rauhuia. This is the true New Zealand flax; the plant which is usually so called being a lily.

rauparaha
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: native convolvulus
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: also pohue
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  1/11/2003
Source:  Dominion Post
Author:
Vol / Page:  E13
Edition:
Quote:  Of course, the introduced, white-flowered convolvulus is not to be confused with our native convolvulus - raparaha or pohue - the small edible namesake of awesome Ngati Toa leader Te Rauparaha. According to the <i>Dictionary of New Zealand Biography</i>, soon after Te Rauparaha's birth, a Waikato warrior who had killed and eaten a relation of his, threatened to eat the child as well, roasted with rauparaha leaves - and the child was named Te Rauparaha in defiance of this threat.
Notes:

Date:  8/11/2001
Source:  Contact (Wgtn)
Author:
Vol / Page:  18
Edition:
Quote:  Introduced white-flowered varieties [convolvulus]are not to be confused with our native convolvulus, rauparaha or pohue. This small edible plant gave its name to the awesome Ngati Toa leader, Te Rauparaha... A coastal plant, rauparaha has curled leaves in a rounded heart-shaped, quite thick and waxy, with pink striped  flowers of the distinctive morning glory form.
Notes:

Notes:

raupatu
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: confiscation [usually of land]
Origin: Maori
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Politics
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations

Edition:
Quote:  "As one who grew up on a farm on raupatu land in the Waikato, where our family's presence felt like it had been for ever, I cannot even begin to imagine the scale of loss felt by Waikato Tainui from the mid-19th century, but I hope that I and my government have played our part in putting right" she [Helen Clark] said.

Notes:

raupo
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: [Ma.] a swamp-growing bulrush Typha orientalis or T augustifolia.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:

Vol / Page:  45

Quote:  A shadow would sometimes darken those eyes coloured light brown, like the velvety heads of raupo.
Notes:

Date:  28/10/1843
Source:  Daily Southern Cross
Author:
Vol / Page:  4
Edition:
Quote:  Houses are built by the natives for the settler in the bush of a species of rush called "Raupo," which is found in abundance in all the swamps, this being cut and dried, neatly tied with strips of "Koradi" or native flax, to a frame-work of wood, and the roof is thatched with a tough species of grass; they are sometimes very tastefully lined with reeds.

Date:  0/0/1834

Vol / Page:  35
Edition:  1963
Quote:  ... the Thatch is the Toie Toie [<i> toetoe </i>] a kind of Flags that is used for the Huts, and an other one more like what our Coopers use for putting between the seams of a Cask, called Rappoo [<i> raupo </i>]. <i>Ibid.</i> 37  [cf COOPERS' FLAG] Rappoo is a Flag or Marsh Reed, used in England by Coopers to put between Staves of Casks; ...


Notes:

Date:  26/2/1840
Source:  Journal
Author:  MATHEW
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  Fairburn's house is built by the natives of what they call `rapou', that is, long reeds matted thickly together and tied ...
Notes:  1840 Feb 26 F.Mathew Journal in 1940 Founding of NZ 63

Date:  0/0/1840
Source:  Manners & Customs of the NZers
Author:  POLACK
Vol / Page:  1/185
Edition:
Quote:   ... and a flax-house at [186] Uwoua, eighty feet long by twenty-four broad and forty feet high to the ridge-pole, was built by a chief and a large company of natives for a small keg of powder 25lbs. in weight. The house was extremely water-tight and warm, and several streams and marshes had been denuded of their rushes  (<i> raupo </i>) to cover the roof and sides; ... <i>Ibid.</I> 1/206 ... a thick coating of bulrushes (<i> raupo </i>) cut from the marshes in the spring, and left to dry during the summer, packed up in long bundles.


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1842
Source:  NZ Reader
Author:
Vol / Page:  122
Edition:
Quote:  `The raupo, the reed-mace of New Zealand, always grows in swampy ground. The leaves or blades when full grown are cut and laid out to dry, forming the common building material with which most native houses are constructed.'


Notes:  1842. W. R. Wade, `A Journey in the North Island of New Zealand,' `New Zealand Reader,' p. 122:

Date:  0/0/1843
Source:  Collection of Ordinances
Author:  DOMETT
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  `Section 2. ... there shall be levied in respect of every building constructed wholly or in part of <i> raupo, nikau, toitoi, wiwi, kakaho </i>, straw or thatch of any description [... 20 [pounds]'


Notes:  1843. `An Ordinance for imposing a tax on Raupo Houses, Session II. No. xvii. of the former Legislative Council of New Zealand': -->[From A. Domett's collection of Ordinances, 1850.]

Author:  DIEFFENBACH
Vol / Page:  1/426
Edition:
Quote:  The same species [Typha augustifolia] is common to both hemispheres. Under the name of repo, or raupo, it is a most useful building-material to the natives ... [bundles of which] they tie together with the mangi-mangi, a climbing fern, the Lygodium articulatum of Achille Richard.

Edition:
Quote:  Green rushes  (<i> Raupo </i>) ..... O. Typhaceae; G. Typha; S. T. angustifolia. `Extensively used for making walls.'
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Austral English
Author:  MORRIS
Vol / Page:  382
Edition:
Quote:  <i> Raupo,  n </i>.  Maori name for a New Zeland bulrush, <i> Typha angustifolia </i>, Linn. The leaves are used for building native houses. The pollen, called <i> Punga-Punga </i> (q.v.), was collected and made into bread called <i> pua </i>. The root was also eaten. It is not endemic in New Zealand, but is known in many parts, and was called by the aborigines of Australia, <i> Wonga </i>, and in Europe `Asparagus of the Cossacks.' Other names for it are <i> Bulrush, Cat's Tail, Reed Mace </i>, and <i> Cooper's Flag </i>.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Merriam-Webster Third International
Author:
Vol / Page:  2030
Edition:
Quote:  <i> Ra&#769;.u-po </i> (rä.&#769;.u-pò.; <i> colloq.</i> rou&#769;.pò.), n. [Maori.] (Bot.) A very common bulrush (<i> Typha angustifolia </i>), much used by Maoris and New Zealand settlers for thatching roofs, and for making hurdles, rafts, etc.  [<i> New Zealand </i>]

Quote:  Another highly curious article of vegetable food was the <i>pungapunga</i>, the yellow pollen of the <i>raupo</i> flowers- the common bulrush, or cat's reed mace (<i>Typha augustifolia</i>... To use it as food it is

mixed up with water into cakes and  baked. It is sweetish and light, and reminds one strongly of London gingerbread.

Notes:

Date:  4/9/1850
Source:  New Zealander, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  3
Edition:
Quote:  We had some eels for breakfast, cooked in a way which was new to most of us, called kohe or kope, and which is done in the following manner:- fern stalks are run down the whole length of the fish (which is not skinned or in any way prepared for cooking) from the mouth to the tail - then two eels thus skewered are wrapped in leaves of the raurekau tree, and tied together with flax, when they are roasted before the fire with one end resting on the ground and the other leaning against a stick supported in a horizontal position in front of the fire for the purpose.
Notes:

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1958
Source:  Queen's English, The
Author:  WALL
Vol / Page:  48
Edition:
Quote:  <i> Sowthistle </i>. Here I note a case of what is called `folk etymology'. I hear this native plant (and introduced weed) as `sour thistle'. The speaker mistrakenly supposes the plant to be named from its taste. It is actually edible and much used by the Maoris as rauriki, corruptly `radicky'.


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1961
Source:  Merriam-Webster Third International
Author:
Vol / Page:  1886
Edition:
Quote:  <i> rauriki n -s [Maori,</i> fr. <i> rau </i> leaf + <i> riki </i> small] <i> NewZeal </i>


Notes:

Date:  22/11/1962
Source:  Evening Post
Author:
Vol / Page:  72
Edition:
Quote:  ... the sow thistle, better known as `rauriki' in the Wellington district, which, marketed [in East Coast and Rotorua districts] as `puha' finds a ready sale.


Notes:

Date:  7/1/1963
Source:  Otago Star
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  If he were sure he could recognise it, writes Mr T. P. Moloney, he would gather rauriki and get his wife to cook it, for he enjoyed it years ago in Maori cooking, in the King Country, where it was called by the pakeha `Maori cabbage.'  <i> Rauriki </i> is the common succulent thistle, growing 2ft to 3ft high, that the children gathering it for pet rabbits and guinea pigs, call milk thistle, because of the abundant flow of milky white sap from it. Actually there are two species' Sonchus oleraceus, whose lobed leaves are only mildly prickly and flat, or at the most very slightly waved at the edges, and S. asper, very similar except that the leaves are much more prickly, and are waved or crimped around the edges. The flowers are yellow, rather like those of a dandelion, about three-quarters of an inch in diameter. <i> Chewing Gum </i>  According to some people, rauriki is the Maori name of the former and puwha of the latter, but I do not know that the Maoris went in for such nice distinctions. Different tribes had different names for the same thing. Puwha, as well as being one of the names for the sow thistle, seems to have been also used sometimes as a general term for any cooked greens, of which sow thistle was the favourite.


Notes:  (I.W.T. Munro on `Maori Cabbage')

Date:  7/1/1963
Source:  Otago Star
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  At Oxford, Makereti (Maggie Papakura) wrote: `I myself gather the sow thistle here and cook it to eat, as it reminds me of our own puwha, of which I am very fond. Puwha was used only as a vegetable ... The succulent stems contained a bitter milky juice which came to the surface when the flower tops were plucked off. This was left, on a sunny day, for a few hours, then gathered between the thumb and first finger, adding the thick creamy mass of several plants together. This was used as a sort of chewing gum, called pia or ngau, which tasted very bitter at first. But after a little chewing, the bitterness disappeared, and this gum was much enjoyed, especially by the women, who vied with each other in seeing who could make her pia crack the loudest.'

Date:  0/0/1886
Source:  Handbook Fishes of NZ
Author:  SHERRIN
Vol / Page:  138
Edition:
Quote:  KOKOPU (<i> Galaxias fasciatus</i>). ... `Kokopu,' Dr. Hector says, `is the general Maori name for several very common fishes in the New Zealand streams and lakes, belonging to the family of <i> Galaxidae</i>. ... The kokopu of the stream is caught by them with bobs; but is not much cared for. Not more, as a rule, than one or two fish will be found in a pool; half a dozen at the most. It is also called rawaru and para.

Vol / Page:  35/319
Edition:
Quote:  ... large numbers of aua or kataha (<i> Agonostoma forsteri</i>); about 60 lb. ... weight of pilchard or mohimohi  (<i> Clupea sagax</i>), two varieties; ... hundreds of young  red-cod, rarii (<i> Lotella bacchus</i>), and what I believe are  young rock-cod, or kokopu or rawaru (<i> Percis colias</i>). The red-cod were from 3 in. to 4 in. in length, and the rawaru, or, as the natives here call them, `toitoi' or `panepane', from 2 in. to 6 in. long.

Date:  0/0/1970
Source:  Nomenclature of NZ Fish
Author:  SORENSON
Vol / Page:  43
Edition:
Quote:  <i>SKATE </i>(a) Scientific name: <i>Raja nasuta.</i> (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Skate. (c) Other common names: Smooth Skate (<i>R. nasuta</i>); Rough Skate (<i>Raja australis</i>); Stingray; Stingaree; Flaps (trade name for Skate `wings'). (d) Principal localities where taken: Napier, Wellington, Nelson, Picton, Banks Peninsula, Timaru, Greymouth.

Citations
Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  Fisherman's Bible
Author:  WILSON
Vol / Page:  28
Edition:
Quote:  BLIND TORPEDO RAY: see <i>Rays (Numbfish)</i>. <i>Ibid.</I>198 BLIND TORPEDO RAY A rare ray, <i>Typhlonarke aysoni</i>, as he is called in Latin, has the ability to emit sparks and make a needle magnetic - yet not to see.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1956
Source:  NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author:  GRAHAM
Vol / Page:  90
Edition:  2nd
Quote:  BLIND TORPEDO RAY OR NUMBFISH <i>Typhlonarke aysoni</i> (Hamilton) [ibid. 92]. This uncommon fish has several names, all of which relate to its manner of producing electric shocks, some of which are Numb-fish, Crampfish and Electric Skate. These vernacular names are given by fishermen on account of the fish benumbing or paralysing the person who unwittingly grasps one with his hands. The last name is from the somewhat similar shape to that of a skate or ray, ray being another common term for skates and also the scientific family name.


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1956
Source:  NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author:  GRAHAM
Vol / Page:  398
Edition:
Quote:  Blind Torpedo-Ray <i>Typhlonarke aysoni</i> (Hutton)


Notes:  1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 398

razoo
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a small or worthless (imaginary) coin; a jot (usu. in neg. constructions)
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: also brass razoo
Pronunciation:
Notes: >ca1920-1930 at least W.H.B. Orsman (brass razoo)

Citations
Date:  20/5/1926
Source:  NZ Truth
Author:
Vol / Page:  13
Edition:
Quote:  In reply to Mr. Curtis's further questioning, Maxwell admitted that he had not a razoo to pay the costs of the action against "Truth" if it went against him.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1941
Source:  NZ Slang
Author:  BAKER
Vol / Page:  52
Edition:
Quote:   razoo ... is in currency for a small coin. The term also has wide use .us;in Australia and ... is heard mainly in the negative phrases I haven't a razoo or I haven't a brass razoo for `I have no money at all'
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1946
Source:  New Zealand (various authors/titles)
Author:  SOLJAK
Vol / Page:  117
Edition:
Quote:  New Zealand colloquialisms which are of Maori origin include; ...  razoo: small coin; from the Maori raho (a trifle).  E.g. I haven't a brass razoo


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1946
Source:  That Summer
Author:  SARGESON

Sense Number:

Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1980
Source:  Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A
Author:  LELAND
Vol / Page:  85
Edition:
Quote:  reader: Literacy is assumed, but not required for this position, an academic rank corresponding with a U.S. PROFESSOR (who is not a department head). Another misleading N.Z. name for the same rank is Associate Professor. For those familiar with the English academic system a Reader in N.Z. is not the same as a Reader in England; as it is a teaching position in N.Z. rather than a research title as in England.

readied

Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: obs.; cf. ready n., ready up v.

Citations
Date:  6/8/1910
Source:  NZ Truth
Author:
Vol / Page:  267/7/2
Edition:
Quote:  Two men (strangers to each other) recently came out of the Police Court after listening to evidence in a case. Said one: `It looks like a "readied" case'; to which the other replied: `Yes.' They said no more and went their several ways; but the joke of the matter lies in the fact that it came out later that the first man intended to libel the police, while the second sought to libel the defence.

Author:  BULLER
Vol / Page:  91
Edition:  {1888 2nd edn 1/85}
Quote:  ANTHORNIS MELANURA. (BELL-BIRD.) ... <i>Native names</i>. Mako, Makomako, Komako, Kokomako, Korimako, Kohimako, Kokorimako, Titimako, and Kopara. Of the above names, Korimako is most generally used by northern and Makomako by southern tribes. The Ngatiawas call this bird Rearea; and the natives of the Bay of Plenty distinguish the male and female as Kokorohimako and Titapu.

Date:  17/11/2001
Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page:  57
Edition:
Quote:  Belich divides the period covered by the volume, the 1880s to the present, into three broad phases: the progressive colonisation which was the dominant feature of <i>Making Peoples</i>; the rise of recolonisation, which tightened the relations between Britain and colonies up to the 1960s and made them co-owners of imperial culture and heritage; and finally decolonisation, the period since the 1960s in which New Zealand has achieved economic diversification, greater independence in foreign policy and a great socio-demographic "coming-out" of difference.
Notes:

Date:  28/10/2001
Source:  Sunday Star Times
Author:
Vol / Page:  C5
Edition:
Quote:  But one pattern looms high above the rest, recolonisation, whose rise, reign and fall is the master variable of modern New Zealand history.

Vol / Page:  12
Edition:
Quote:  By recolonisation he means the powerful tightening of economic, social and cultural ties to Britain that began in the 1880s and lasted till the 1970s.  It turned New Zealand into "a town-supply district of London" while "London became the cultural capital of New Zealand."

Belich dubs this era, which followed four decades of colonisation, as New Zealand's "recolonised" period. It was a time of tightened economic and cultural links to Britain and a role for this country as Britains "town supply district".

red
Homonym Number:
Word Class: adjective
Sense Number:
Definition: as a distinguishing epithet in names of plants see AZOLLA, BEECH; BEECH, SOUTHERN; BIDDY-BID, BIRCH; BURR, NEW ZEALAND; CAMPION, CENTAURY, CESTRUM, CLOVER, DEAD NETTLE, FAT HEN; FERN, WATER; FIR; GRASS, FESCUE; GUM, HEATH, HOROPITO, ink plant, KAMAHI, KIEKIE, KOWHAI, MALLOW, MANUKA, MAPAU, MAPLE, MATIPO, MISTLETOE, MYRTLE, ORACHE, PARROT'S BILL, PINE, PIRIPIRI; RATA, CLIMBING; RUSH; TARWEED, TEA-TREE, TUSSOCK, UNCINIA, VALERIAN -->as a distinguishing epithet in names of fish see: BAITFISH, COD; COD, ROCK; CRAB, SWIMMING; CRAYFISH, DORY, GURNARD, GURNET(-PERCH), HERRING, MOKI, MULLET, PERCH; COD, ROCK; SCORPIONFISH, SNAPPER, SOLDIER(FISH), SPOTTY, SQUID: see also RED BAIT, REDFISH

Quote:  The contestants all regular attendees at the Stadium designed the concept of the Golden Gumboot while celebrating Mercy's win last Sunday. Racing over 200 metres the contestants are racing in a costume (including mask) of their choice and must wear red bands.
Notes:  www.greyhounds.co.nz/aticles/article_2007_05_23_2432.html

Date:  0/0/1918
Source:  NZ Journal of Science & Technology
Author:
Vol / Page:  1/308
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Fagus fusca</i>. - In Auckland this tree is called `black-birch'; in Wellington `red-birch'; in Nelson, Marlborough and Westland it is called `brown-birch'; and in Otago it is called both `red-birch' and `bull-birch.' The most suitable name is `red-beech.'
Notes:  (E. Phillips Turner)

Date:  0/0/1883
Source:  Handbook of New Zealand
Author:  HECTOR
Vol / Page:  125
Edition:  3rd
Quote:  <i>Nothofagus fusca</I>, Hook. Tawhai Tawhairaunui, Black-birch of Auckland and Otago (from colour of bark), Red-birch of Wellington and Nelson (from colour of timber). --This is a noble tree 60-90 feet high the trunk 5-8 feet in diameter. The timber is excessively tough and hard to cut. It is highly valued in Nelson and Wellington.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1885
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  17/300
Edition:
Quote:  <i> [Notho]fagus fusca,</I> Hook. f. ... Tooth-leaved Beech. Black Birch of Auckland and in part of Otago and Southland. Black or Bull Birch of Lake Wakatipu. Red Birch of Wellington, Nelson, and in part of Otago and Southland. It is not so easy to see why any difficulty should have occured in the identification of this fine timber-tree apart from the misleading tendency of the common names generally applied. The thin yet firm texture of the leaf, the prominent veins, the sharply-toothed margins, are characters that can only be confused with those afforded by a careless observer. Yet merely owing to the use of common names based upon colour, and applied or rather misapplied to the leaves, bark, or wood at the fancy of the bushman, no species has been more misunderstood.
Notes:  (Kirk, NZ Beeches)

Date:  0/0/1889

Date:  11/3/1972
Source:  Otago Daily Times
Author:
Vol / Page:  1
Edition:
Quote:   Colour Coding [heading] ... St Patrick's Day sports organiser, Mr Lyn Thompson yesterday inquired about the difference between red, black and brown birch. It was `clearly' explained for him by a prominent axeman, Mr Bill Evans. The bark of the red birch is silver, [?HWO thus <i>N. menziesii</i>] but the timber is pink when it's green. Brown birch often has black bark, but the green timber is red. Sometimes the bark of the black birch is white, but the timber is yellow and sometimes it's brown when it's green.
Notes:  (Griffiths Collection)

Quote:  <i>[Notho]fagus solandri</i>, Hook. f. ... <i>Myrtilloides cinerascens</i>, Banks & Sol., MS. <i>Cliffortiordes oblongata,</i> Dryander. Entire-leaved Beech. Black Birch of Wellington, Canterbury, and in part of Otago and Southland. White Birch of Nelson, and in part Otago. Black-heart Birch of Otago. White, Black, Red, and Brown Birch of Oxford and Alford Forests. A fine tree, sometimes attaining the height of 100 feet, but usually 60-80 feet, with a trunk from 2 to 4 feet or more in diameter.
Notes:  (Kirk, NZ Beeches)

red cod
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: Pseudophycis bachus (also listed as <I>Physiculus bac(c)hus, </i>

and in early texts <I>Lotella bacchus</i>), fam Moridae, an often abundant food fish of mainly SI waters; .in early writings under a listing <I>Lotella bacchus,</i> occas. and confusingly referred to as rock cod or yellowtail qqv.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Contrast bastard red cod.

(d) Principal localities where taken: Cook Strait, Nelson, Picton ... Lyttelton, Akaroa, Timaru, Port Chalmers, Greymouth.

Red Fed
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: originally one who supported the socialist ideals and policies of the `Red' Federation of Labour; a RED FEDERAL; (informal) a socialist or leftist; a slightly abusive term for a left-wing `agitator', militant unionist, or other assertive person of the left
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]

The Reds are out to fight ...' The tramwaymen struck and won, and henceforth that first Federation of Labour became known as the Red Federation and its leaders as Red Feds.

Red Federation
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1993
Source:  Wharfie
Author:
Vol / Page:  p28
Edition:
Quote:  On the West Coast the miners Federation changed its name to New Zealand Federation of Labour (soon known as the red Federation, or simply the Red Fed) and sent out organisers to win support from other unions.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1925
Source:  Red Fed. Memoirs
Author:  HICKEY
Vol / Page:  48
Edition:
Quote:   ... I issued a  circular, stating that the Federation would stand behind the tramwaymen in any action that they might take.  I had no authority whatever for issuing the circular, and in looking back on that time now, can only account for my impetuous action through my anger at the contempt displayed towards organised Labour by the City Council and the press. The leaflet (which happened to be printed on red paper, this giving the idea to the `Evening Post' [in early 1912] that was responsible for the coining of the term `Red Federation,' which was afterwards abbreviated to `Red Fed.') caused a wave of militancy to sweep through the tramway service, and a meeting was called for the p.m. shift the following day.


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1957
Source:  History of NZ Life, A
Author:  MORRELL & HALL
Vol / Page:  207
Edition:
Quote:  A conference in 1910 with the Dominion Exective of the Trades and Labour Councils failed to achieve unity, and next year the Councils brought their own Federation into being. In the competition for support which followed, the militant Federation, which its opponents nicknamed the `Red Federation', had valuable assets in the eloquence of its leaders and the propaganda of its organ The Maoriland Worker.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1959
Source:  History of New Zealand
Author:  SINCLAIR
Vol / Page:  198
Edition:
Quote:  In 1908 there was a local strike [on the West Coast] and shortly afterwards the miners formed a Federation of Labour to which, within a few years, were affiliated most of the miners and water side workers. The 1912 constitution of the `Red Federation' began with the preamble of the IWW ...

"Farmers in the North Island," he said, "were giving their whole-hearted support to the Liberals, and although the Prime Minister was endeavouring to make party capital out of 'Red-Fedism,' the farmers had not forgotten that the Government had helped to secure the return of active supporters of the Red-Fed. movement."

Vol / Page:  356

Quote:  Some of the timber trees are of large growth, particularly three sorts; the first is of the pine tribe and is known by the name of Pimise (Pinus??) in three varieties on the north. The second is something like the Lucombe Oack, and the third is called the Red Gum or Eucalipticus I have seen it in England. ... The three varieties of pine are very tall and handsome, and one in appearance like the Lucombe oak grows tall but not so straight, the Eucalipticy grows to a great thickeness in the stem and frequently not less than fifteen feet in girt but not more than 15 or 20 feet in height before it spreads its large branches in every direction, ...

Vol / Page:  201
Edition:
Quote:  The common Red Gurnard (<i>Chelidonichthys kumu</i>) and the larger, but less common Spotted Gurnard  (<i>Pterygotrigla picta</i>) are `mail-cheek' fishes (order SCLEROPAREI), which are perch-like in all but that the head and the gill-covers are strongly armoured and freely studded with strong spines.

Date:  0/0/1907
Source:  Plants of NZ
Author:  LAING & BLACKWELL
Vol / Page:  332
Edition:  1940 p. 353
Quote:  <i> [Suttonia australis (The Red Matipo)]</i> ... Native name <i>Mapau, Mapou</i>, or

<i>Matipo</i>. The name Matipo is generally applied by Europeans to <i>Pittosporum tenuifolium</i>, but this is apparently the plant to which the Maoris attached it. This tree bears some resemblance to <i>Pittosporum tenuifolium</i>, but can be readily distinguished by the reddish colour of the leaves. [<i>Rapanea Urvillei,</i> 1907]
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1940
Source:  Te Waimate
Author:  STUDHOLME

Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: butterfly perch
Pronunciation:
Notes: <i>Caesioperca lepidoptera</i> aka butterfly perch, red snapper, St. Peter's Fish, or bastard long-fin'

Citations
Date:  23/7/1986
Source:  Codes for Species in NZ Waters
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  [species name] alfonsino .. [scientific name] <i>Beryx splendens </i>.. [other name(s)] red perch (name used by Sealord (Nelson))
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1957
Source:  Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ
Author:  PARROTT
Vol / Page:  73
Edition:
Quote:  The Red Perch, as is the case with many of our common fishes, has received many popular names. .../ It is also known as the `Red Snapper', `St. Peter's Fish' or `Butterfly erch'. It probably received the name of `St. Peter's Fish' on account of the two black marks, one on each side of the body, which suggest the thumb/and finger marks of St. Peter, as I have previously explained in the case of the John Dory. ... One of the popular names in Australia for [Red Perch] is `Butterfly Perch', so called from its specific name <i>Lepidoptera. </i>

Vol / Page:  233
Edition:
Quote:  RED PERCH (OIA) <i>Caesioperca lepidoptera</i>(Bloch and Schneider)
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1957
Source:  Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ
Author:  PARROTT
Vol / Page:  72
Edition:
Quote:  THE RED PERCH <i>Caesioperca lepidoptera</i>(Bloch & Schneider)... <i>Maori name: OIA. </I> <i>Ibid.</I> 73 The Red Perch, as is the case with many of our common fishes, has received many popular names. It is known in Australia as the `Bastard Long-fin', a name probably associated with its long dorsal fin. It is also known as the `Red Snapper', `St. Peter's Fish' or `Butterfly Perch'. It probably received the name of `St. Peter's Fish' on account of the two black marks, one on each side of the body, which suggest the thumb/and finger marks of St. Peter, as I have previously explained in the case of the John Dory.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1957
Source:  Dictionary of the Maori Language

Notes:  (Monro)

red pine
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: rimu,  used instead of rimu in very early days of the North Island settlements probably before European settlers became accustomed to the Maori word: ?esp. a bushmen's use; occas. used as a descriptive generic (from colour of wood) for other genera and species; (In New Zealand) - <i>Dacrydium cupressinum</i>, Soland; called also <i>Rimu</i>(q.v.). ...
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: <I>Rimu </i>has replaced <I>Red-pine</i> in the North Island and in Marlborough, Nelson and Westland; in Canterbury and Otago (and to some extent Westland) the timber has up to fairly recently always, and the tree chiefly, been <I>Red-pine,</i> although `<I>Rimu</i>' was by no means unknown, and by 1984 had generally replaced <I>Red-pine</i> except perhaps in the South South Island. ca1952 Dunedin `It's built out of red-pine; you know, timber from a rimu-tree'. ca1952 Hollyford Valley Red-pine (the tree), never <i>rimu </i>; (In Australia) - <i>Frenela endlicheri</i>, Parlat.
Citations
Date:  27/5/1871
Source:  Otago Witness
Author:
Vol / Page:  5
Edition:
Quote:  Mr. M'Gruer prides himself a good deal on the specimen of the rimu or red pine (<i> Dacrydium cupressinum </i>) which he had transplanted from the bush, and which is a plant very difficult to start.
Notes:

Date:  22/6/1912

Date:  0/5/1821
Source:  Evidence of McDonald before Commissioner Bigge
Author:  McDONALD
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  Q. Are there many harbours there [on the west side of New Zealand]? A. Several ... All covered with wood Q. Of what sort? A. Of white and red pine and a wood called `black oak'.

Q. Is it of the species called `kaikatua'? A. It is. Q. Did you see any of the species called `cowrie'? A. I did not. <I>Ibid.</I> 1/560 Q. Whereabouts do the red and white pine trees grow? A. The white pine grows in wet swampy places. The red pine grows on the sides of hills. Q. Is the red pine like the cowrie? A. It is the same grain, but not the same color.
Notes:  1821 May Evidence of McDonald before Commissioner Bigge in 1908 McNab Historical Records 1/559

Region: [none]

Source:  NZ Journal of Science & Technology
Author:
Vol / Page:  4/121
Edition:
Quote:  SCORPAENA CARDINALIS Richardson. <I>Red Rock-cod; Matuawhapuku</I>. Very common throughout the year in rocky localities around North Auckland Peninsula, but not greatly utilized as a food fish. Distribution: A northern species; occasionally seen on the northern and western coasts of the South Island.

See:

Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1986
Source:  NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author:  PAUL
Vol / Page:  150
Edition:
Quote:  <i> Red rock lobster Jasus edwardsii </i>... Closely  related to <i> J. novaehollandiae </i> of southern Australia and <i> J. lalandii </i> of South Africa ... `Crayfish' has been regularly used as a common name, although it is more properly applied to freshwater species. Some combination of `red', `spiny', and `rock lobster' is more appropriate.

Source:  Bush Boys of NZ
Author:  THOMSON
Vol / Page:  84
Edition:
Quote:  Others wanted [to play] `Prisoners' Base'` or `Chivvy', `Brewer', `Egg-in-the hat', `Duck-stone', `Red Rover', or `Kingy-seeny'. The boys did not know where this east game came from. They did not know its proper spelling or pronunciation. `Kingy-Seeny' it was to them and they did not care whether that had a meaning or not. This rough and tumble game was the most popular of all.

Date:  0/0/1957
Source:  Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ
Author:  PARROTT
Vol / Page:  73
Edition:
Quote:  The Red Perch, as is the case with many of our common fishes, has received many popular names. .../ It is also known as the `Red Snapper', `St. Peter's Fish' or `Butterfly Perch' It probably received the name of `St. Peter's Fish' on account of the two black marks, one on each side of the body, which suggest the thumb/and finger marks of St. Peter, as I have previously explained in the case of the John Dory.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  Fisherman's Bible
Author:  WILSON
Vol / Page:  114
Edition:
Quote:  GOLDEN SNAPPER Not a snapper at all but a relative of the Roughy. This big-eyed, Golden (or Red) Snapper is usually taken accidentally when bottom fishing for snapper. <I>Ibid.</i> 227 Red snapper or sometimes reef snapper, is a name given to those fish which have spent a good part of their time in rough-bottom areas; they are a deeper, golden red than the normal open-water snapper.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1982
Source:  Collins Guide
Author:  AYLING
Vol / Page:  177
Edition:  1984
Quote:   <i>GOLDEN SNAPPER Centroberyx affinis (Trachichthodes affinis) </i>(Nannygai, red snapper, koarea) ... In spite of its name the golden snapper is not related to the true snapper and is in fact more similar to the roughys. ... Schools of golden snapper often move out over open sand flats ... and are then regularly caught in bottom trawls and sold as red fish.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1986
Source:  NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author:  PAUL
Vol / Page:  72
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Red snapper Trachichthodes affinis </i> Alternatively the golden snapper, and redfish or nannygai in southern Australia.

red sticker
Homonym Number:
Word Class: verb
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: to apply, or have applied, a red sticker; in Wellington this indicates the highest risk of earthquake damage, while in Chch it indicates the highest outcome of earthquake damage and renders a property unusable.   The verb appears most often as red stickered.  Abbreveiated to red, and redded

red sticker
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: The label indicating highest level of earthquake damage and renders a building unusable;  Christchurch origin but spreading to other centres where the indication is of risk rather than damage.
Citations
Date:  19/3/2011
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  8
Edition:
Quote:  The red sticker is not a demolition order. It means the building is either so damaged there is a risk of collapse or nearby unstable buildings pose a safety threat. Civil Defence figures show that as of Thursday, 42 buildings have been demolished, with 94 partially "deconstructed".

The old brick lady was wrapped in red tape, the warning notice was stuck on the garage door and the neighbour's garden cordoned off. Our house was deemed unsafe to inhabit. .. The red sticker was a moment of clarity. The house was unsafe while the aftershocks were occurring; walk away.

Date:  4/12/1989

Vol / Page:  18
Edition:
Quote:  ...it may be prudent to mention that the Australian red-back spider (<i>Latrodectus hasselti</i>) has become firmly established in New Zealand in the last couple of years, so we can deal with three closely related comb-footed spider species in the space of one story... In other words, the black widow is really nothing more than the American katipo, and the red-back is the Australian katipo.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1961
Source:  Merriam-Webster Third International
Author:
Vol / Page:  1900
Edition:
Quote:  redback spider  : a theridiid spider (<i.Latrodectus hasselti</i>) that is closely related to the American black widow and prob. identical with the katipo, has a venom which produces neurotoxic symptoms in man, and occurs in Australia, New Zealand, and the major islands of the East Indies - called also <i>red-streaked spider </i>

Sense Number:

In spite of its name the golden snapper is not related to the true snapper and is in fact more similar to the roughys. ... Schools of golden snapper often move out over open sand flats ... and are then regularly caught in bottom trawls and sold as red fish.

(RED-FRONTED PARRAKEET.) ... <i>Native names.</i> Kakariki, Kakawariki, Powhaitere, Porere, and Torete ...[59] The Red-fronted Parrakeet is very generally dispersed over the whole country - but is more plentiful in the southern portion of the North Island than in the far north, where the yellow-fronted species predominates.

Quote:  The redheads we soon began catching for ourselves: smaller and less flavoursome than the inanga, the prized main whitebait variety (there are five in all), the redheads did indeed have a small flush of red colouring behind their heads. They also possess two sets of fins - all the better for climbing up waterfalls, and for climbing part-way up the sides of our bucket.

Definition: (Occasionally) =willow weed
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: redroot
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1926
Source:  Weeds of New Zealand
Author:  HILGENDORF
Vol / Page:  126
Edition:  1967
Quote:  WILLOW WEED (Epilobium sp[p].). - This is also called herb willow, swamp willow, and by confusion redshank and fireweed. It is a native that occasionally grows as a weed in or near ditches. The name is sometimes given to redshank [p.59], and it is true that both polygonum and epilobium grow in damp places, have willow-like leaves and are about 2 feet high.


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1969
Source:  Standard Common Names for Weeds

Vol / Page:  63
Edition:
Quote:  <i>redshank [=] redroot: willow weed: pale willow weed [s] </i>

Quote:  WILLOW WEED OR REDSHANK (<i>Polygonum persicaria</i>) ... This cosmopolitan weed is common throughout New Zealand, mainly in cultivated ground.
Notes:

redshank
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number: 2
Definition: persicaria, spotted persicaria, knot weed, smart weed,=willow weed, lady's thumb, ? water pepper, ? walker's weed


Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1926
Source:  Weeds of New Zealand
Author:  HI;LGENDORF
Vol / Page:  59
Edition:  1967
Quote:  REDSHANK (<i>Polygonum persicaria</i>) is also called persicaria, spotted persicaria, knot weed, smart weed, willow weed, and lady's thumb. Perhaps also it is this weed that on the west coast of the South Island is called water pepper or Walker's weed. It is an annual weed of gardens, crops, and wet pastures.

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Austral English
Author:  MORRIS
Vol / Page:  385
Edition:
Quote:  term in gold-mining; a vein of auriferous quartz. Called by the Calfornian miners a vein, or lode, or ledge. In Bendigo, the American  usage remains, the words reef, dyke and vein being used  as synonymous, though reef is the most common. (See quotation, 1866.)  In Ballarat, the word has two distinct meanings, viz. the vein, as above, and the bed-rock or true-bottom. quotations, ...1869 and 1874.) Outside Australia, a reef means `a chain or range of rocks lying at or near the surface of the water.' (Webster.')


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1929
Source:  Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.
Author:
Vol / Page:  9
Edition:
Quote:  ~ n. a vein of gold-bearing quartz;-v.t. to work at a reef.

Date:  0/0/1966

Edition:
Quote:   ~ n. vein of auriferous quartz

Date:  0/0/1978
Source:  Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary)
Author:  McARA
Vol / Page:  330
Edition:
Quote:  Reefs: The quartz veins which were contained in the country rocks at Waihi. They were more correctly described as fissure veins; the term `reefs' is considered to be more appropriately applied to them than the term  `lodes' formerly used.

Date:  27/11/1993
