Vol / Page:  17
Edition:
Quote:  [He] has been overseas some of the time,

running foreign exchange dealing rooms in

Hong Kong and Los Angeles, and the term

"reef fish" is new to him. I have to

explain that it's a derisive term coined

by David Lange to describe the behaviour

of the money markets... Lange once

referred to market operators as demented

reef fish - a term inspired by the

aberrant behaviour of tropical fish which

dart backwards and forwards en masse in a

manner that defies rational explanation.

reference sire

Sense Number:  1
Definition: [stud stock breeding] a select and closely studied ram or bull used for artificial insemination.

Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  27/9/2002
Source:  Dominion Post
Author:
Vol / Page:  C7
Edition:
Quote:  Some reference sires are used in successive years to create genetic links, which allows EBVs to be compared across years. Other reference sires are replaced by superior rams, identified by their across-flock EBVs. Thus the reference sires have a dual role, creating genetic links across flocks and years and producing more rapid dissemination of genetic improvement.

Notes:

Date:  0/1/1999
Source:  NZWords
Author:
Vol / Page:  2
Edition:
Quote:  At  the  other end  of  the  scale  is  the indeterminate   sentence   of   preventive detention.  A sentence of the same name existed  in  Britain  from  1908 to  1967. Introduced in New Zealand in 1954 to replace the sentence of reformative detention (1910) and declaration as an habitual offender and habitual criminal (1906), it remains very much alive here.

Notes:

Rehab
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: the Rehabilitation Department, which was set up to help servicemen returned from World War II.


Origin: abbreviation
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Formed [?d] and ceased as a separate department [?d]: also freq. attrib. or in combin. REHAB. DEPARTMENT, -LOAN (special low interest loans to servicemen), -MONEY etc; and used a a noun. `Rehab. is fixing me  up with a loan' or, esp., `I got my loan under Rehab.' referring to the Department or its officers or policies in general. Contract with NZ WW1 repat qv, and British and Austr. Repat.  WW2 (1952 Apr 28 Bluey and Curly, Austr cartoon, use repat. (R.Mason). The abbrev. is the usual  or expected one: (cf Part: rehab. official abbrev. of rehabilitation ward or department in a hospital since ca1945)
Citations
Date:  6/8/1947
Source:  NZ Observer
Author:
Vol / Page:  11
Edition:
Quote:  The smaller ones [sc. builders], however, are shying away.. from "rehab. jobs".

Quote:  In his chart Too-gee has marked an imaginary road which goes the lengthways of Ea-hei-no-mawe, viz. from Cook's Strait to the North Cape, which Too-gee calls Terry-inga. While the soul is received by the good Ea-tooa, an evil spirit is also in readiness to carry the impure part of the corpse to the above road, along which it is carried to Terry-inga, whence it is precipitated into the sea.

Date:  23/6/1833
Source:  Early Journals of Henry Williams, The
Author:  WILLIAMS
Vol / Page:  320
Edition:  1961
Quote:  They had much to say about Te Uarahi having died and after taking a survey of the Reinga returned to deliver his account. [ed fn] Te Reinga, the abode of the dead. It was the Maori belief that the dead travelled to Te Reinga [lit., `the leaping place'] at the northernmost tip of the North Island, and there jumped over the cliff into the place of the dead.


Notes:

Date:  0/12/1834
Source:  Journal
Author:  W.G. PUCKEY
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  The whole body of New Zealanders firmly believe in the Reinga as the only one place for their departed spirits. As soon as the soul leaves the body it makes its way with all speed to the western coast; if the spirit of a person who resided in the interior, it takes with it a small bundle of the branches of the palm tree as a token of the place where it resided; if one who lived on the coast, the spirit takes with it a kind of grass which grows by the seaside, which it leaves at different places on the road to the Reinga.


Notes:  1834 Dec W.G.Puckey Journal in 1863 Maning Old New Zealand (1948 edn) 318

Quote:  This cliff was called the Re-i-nga, i.e., the leaping-place. Some who lived near this spot used to affirm that on certain nights they could hear the rush of the spirits as they passed on their way.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1938
Source:  Brown Man's Burden
Author:  FINLAYSON
Vol / Page:  3, 134
Edition:  1973
Quote:  The time was opportune for another feat-day. ... there had not been a marriage ... for months now; and among the long-lived little community, neither had the occasion for a tangi arisen, altough it was evident that poor old Honi Tawa was not far now from the road to the Reinga. [134 ed. note] 2. `not far from the road to Reinga.' [sic] A traditional Maori way of saying close to death, when the spirit of the dead was said to join its ancestors in the mythical homeland of the Maoris, Hawaiki, across the Pacific Ocean, departing fom New Zealand at Cape Reinga.
Notes:  (Wedding gift)

Edition:
Quote:  relief: a Government work scheme for unemployed during the depression. Relief work was often part-time and often work of little perceivable immediate value -- clearing drains, grubbing gorse, draining swamps, making roads, planting trees, etc.

religo

Sense Number:

Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: cf. hoon
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1953
Source:  Till Human Voices Wake Us
Author:  HAMILTON
Vol / Page:  154
Edition:
Quote:  They reckoned he'd stuck to his religion all  through and the Hoons [fn Non religious groups.] gave me the impression that he took his religion seriously and to them he was a bit of a joke. You couldn't take much notice of the Hoons of course, not about a thing like that. Most of them just lumped the religoes together ... <I> Ibid.</i> 164 There was a sort of line drawn in the [detention] camps betwen the Hoons and the religoes. ... The religoes were divided again into God knows how many sects and amongst the hoons were absolute pacifists, pacifists, Communists, Anarchists, humanists, and plain dodgers.

<i>Ibid.</i> 215 The third group [in conscientious objectors' detention camps], the religoes, could hardly be called a group at all. It was a mixed bag of Methodists, Presbyterians, Brethren, Church of England and some Catholics.

Origin:

Domain: [none]

Date:  15/5/2004
Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page:  46
Edition:
Quote:  Relish can also be used in a generic sense to mean a spoonful of something tasty served to enhance a plain food, although in New Zealand a relish is usually a sweetened savoury preserve made of chopped or grated vegetables - occasionally fruit - in which the vegetables retain some firmness of texture. Therefore, you could say that a New Zealand relish is a type of pickle, or that a New Zealand pickle is a type of relish.

That is the word `naughty', for sexual intercourse.

remit

Sense Number:
Definition: a recommendation sent by a branch or by an affiliated organisation of a body to the main body (often an annual conference) for consideration, and possible adoption and action.

Vol / Page:  20

Notes:

Date:  26/4/1853
Source:  Traveller under Concern
Author:  MACKIE
Vol / Page:  102
Edition:  1973
Quote:  This inn - the Wakatu - is the most disorderly and uncomfortable house that we have seen in the colonies. It is frequented by young men of some education with a little money, and whilst their money lasts they give themselves up to riot and excess. They are probably such as their friends in England are glad to send to a distance and as if to confirm their ruin supply them with a small income. As soon as this is squandered they go to the Wairau as shepherds ... Here they remain in obscurity till their remittance brings them again to the Wakatu.


Notes:

Date:  20/7/1861

Vol / Page:  61
Edition:  1914
Quote:  A few days later he came, and told me his story, common enough in Australia, but at present much less so in New Zealand, where we have fewer of those failures at home who are sent out to the Colonies, in the faint hope that a man who is a ne'er-do-well in England will succeed elsewhere, and in too many cases sent out with the promise of small remittances, to be out of sight and out of mind.

remittance man
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition:  a victim of the British class system paid to live and work in New Zealand to avoid bringing shame to his family in the home country [usually employed in rural areas as shepherd, boundary keeper, musterer etc.]


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:

The answer received was "Paid for your telegram and this - balance per mail." He is now waiting for the mail that will bring him about enough to acknowledge the receipt by post.

remittancer
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a remittance man
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1888
Source:  Antipodean Notes
Author:  D'AVIGDOR
Vol / Page:  169
Edition:
Quote:  [Colonialisms] A `remittancer' in Australia is a ne'er-do-well who has been sent out from

England by his friends and receives a monthly remittance  as long as he [170] keeps away. No one will give a `remittancer' work if he can obtain anybody else to do it, and the remittancer generally spends his monthly allowance in three days, living very badly on credit till his

money next arrives.)


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1960
Source:  Memories of Maoriland
Author:  SCRYMGEOUR
Vol / Page:  157
Edition:
Quote:  Another memory that lingered on the trip, was that from Napier to Gisborne, to inspect a property known as `Te Rapa' and nearby was a `pubbery' (certainly not a hotel, for anybody would wonder why the Licensed Victuallers Association ever granted a licence for meals or liquor to be dispensed), and was typically designated `The Trap'. Truly, this pubbery was just short of shanty, typical of the `Outer Barcoo', but where Maories, their Wahines, or broken down `Remittancers' could drown their sorrows, wander into the `arms of Bacchus' or chase pink elephants.

Quote:  Rengarenga, Rock Lily... The plant is sometimes known as renga lily or Mabel Island lily (after an island of this name near Picton, where the plant is particularly striking). An alternative Maori name for the plant, maikika, is shared with two native orchids that have similar, starchy, edible root-like tubers.

Source:  Towards Taha Maori
Author:  HOWE
Vol / Page:  22
Edition:
Quote:  Reo - while the word is often translated as 'the language', this explanation hides the fact that the Maori language is revered as a living record of its people, and enshrines the ethos of the people. No one can fully know `te reo' unless one is acquainted with the proverbs, legends, histories and knowledge of all tribal groups and areas. Yet it is a lifetime work knowing 'te reo' of one's own tribal area.

Date:  0/0/1928
Source:  BP Bishop Memoirs
Author:
Vol / Page:  IX No. 5 pp. 343-382)
Edition:
Quote:  358 ... the most important [Chatham Island] edible sea-birds:

AS WRITTEN AS PRONOUNCED ENGLISH  hopo ho[macron]p' albatross  hakoakoa ha[macron]ko[macron]k' mutton bird taiko tchai[macron]k' pied shear water tupoupou tchu[macron]poup' pied blue billie reoreo ro[macron]ro[macron] Mother Carys chicken

turiwati tchu[macron]riwat' dottrel [sic] kuaka ku[macron]k' snipe


Notes:  1928 Baucke Manuscript in Skinner and Baucke The Morioris (Bishop Museum Memoirs Vol. IX No. 5 pp. 343-382)

repertory
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: In England a repertory theatre is usually one with a professional cast who perform a repertoire of plays, changing plays, say, once a week. In NZ it is merely the name of an amateur theatre group, undistinguished from other such groups except (in Wellington at least) in the more popular appeal of the plays performed. (J. Wright). 1963 (Also, as General English, the Rep).


Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
repile
Homonym Number:
Word Class: verb
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: reblock
Pronunciation:
Notes: Jim writes: DNZE records the special NZ use of <i>pile</i> and <i>block</i> [or post] of wood or stone [or concrete] on which the underfloor beams of a building rest. It does not have entries for <i>repile</i> or <i>reblock</i>. These terms are in common use and often seen in ads for old houses e.g. "recently repiled", "needs some reblocking". "Repiling" is a heading in the Yellow Pages.

Date:  0/0/1855
Source:  Te Ika a Maui
Author:  TAYLOR
Vol / Page:  415
Edition:
Quote:  Papaka, the crab: the largest is about two and a half inches across the carapace; a small crab, called the rerepari, abounds in the salt marshes. There is also a small crab found in the mussel, which has a very round red body and short legs. I have met with a little fresh-water crab, seventy miles inland; it is not above half an inch across the shell, delicately formed, of a dusky green color. There is no lobster in New Zealand.

It is proposed that, with the exception of lands reserved or granted in trust for the purposes before-mentioned, all the lands of the Colony should be sold progressively, as surveys shall be completed ...

Resident Magistrate
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: an official stationed in various towns and settlements, having minor judicial and (particularly in frontier areas) administrative functions, especially in relation to Maori matters.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Jim Cameron writes : Historical 1846-1893. Shorn of administrative duties, resident magistrates were metamorphosed into <i>stipendiary magistrates</i> in the 1890s and legal qualifications were required. The term is not unique to NZ; there were resident magistrates in Ireland and elsewhere, but never in England. They played a significant part in NZ History which is recounted in Aland Ward <i>A Show of Justice</i> (1974). Not recorded in DNZE or other dictionaries, except perfunctorily (without definition) in NSOD.

Citations
Date:  0/0/1999
Source:  NZWords
Author:
Vol / Page:  2(1) : 1
Edition:
Quote:  Resident magistrates, especially in frontier districts, were agents of government as well as having judicial functions. Towards the end of the nineteenth century resident magistrates lost their administrative functions and their office was metamorphosed into the purely judicial one of stipendiary magistrate.    Generally  known  simply  as magistrates (or SMs) they were legally qualified and exercised increasingly important judicial functions in magistrates courts
Notes:

resource consent
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Jim Cameron writes : This is not recorded in DNZE but is in NZPOD. There are no entries in that dictionary for the different types of resource consent - <i>land use consent, subdivision consent, coastal permit, water permit, discharge permit</i>. See Resource Management Act, 1991, s. 87 for definitions.

Resource Management Act
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: a controversial natural resource protection act of 1991, that gives instruction to landowners on how weeds, pests, water, mineral, topographical, and other resources on their properties are to be managed.

Region: [none]

restaurant
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:

Sense Number:

Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Jim Cameron writes : Introduced by the Harassment Act 1997, it is a milder counterpart to a <i>protection order</i> under the Domestic Violence Act. (The NZOD definition is confusing and the example incorrect).

reti
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1943
Source:  Eighty Years
Author:  MANNERING
Vol / Page:  156
Edition:
Quote:  The Maoris used to fish there [mouth of Tukituki River, Hawke's Bay ca1897] with `reti' ... The reti consists of a canoe-shaped board about a foot long with a spinning bait attached with about four feet of strong line. The board is thrown into the current on its edge and is held against the current and allowed to drift out into the breakers, generally on about 100 yards of line. The moment a fish is struck the whole affair is brought in.
Notes:

return-race/return-race shed
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: an internal-race model of woolshed where sheep go to a pen behind, and at the same level as, the board, once shorn.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]

Notes:

Date:  27/11/1975
Source:  NZ Farmer
Author:
Vol / Page:  14
Edition:
Quote:  Return-race sheds may use space inefficiently but they do have certain advantages. Shorn sheep go to the back of the shed by return races which are on the same level as the pens and board. The return races can also be used for footrotting, inocculating and drafting. Unwelcome draughts are avoided in an internal-race shed.
Notes:

Date:  24/4/1980
Source:  NZ Farmer
Author:
Vol / Page:  36
Edition:

Vol / Page:  1945

Quote:  <i>rewa-rewa n</i> -s [Maori] 1 : a slender New Zealand tree  (<i>Knightia excelsa</I> ) resembling the Lombardy poplar in habit but yielding a valuable timber 2 : the strong heavy mottled red wood of the rewa-rewa - called also <i>New Zealand honeysuckle </i>

Sense Number:
Definition: leaven or leavened Maori bread
Origin: Maori
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: a transliteration of leaven; see also rewena bread, paraoa

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1966
Source:  Kapiti Coast
Author:  CARKEEK
Vol / Page:  52
Edition:
Quote:  The Maori word for bread is paraoa which is a trans-literation of the word flour. Various kinds of bread were made by the whalers, traders, and missionaries and some of them survive today and are regarded by present-day Maoris as non-Pakeha items of diet. One of these is called rewena (leaven) bread, another is the panakeke, or pancake-type bread.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1992
Source:  Mihipeka
Author:  EDWARDS
Vol / Page:  29

Quote:  I've a big rewena bread for lunch, made

in the camp oven, brown and crusty.

Quote:  In shape, they are usually long, deep and very much compressed and flattened on the sides, so much so that their local appellations always embody some idea of these peculiarities - such as ribband-fish, lath or deal fish, band fish or blade-fish, and also oar-fish.

Domain: [none]
Region: [none]

Notes: aka Lacebark.  The tallest of three main ribbonwoods / lacebarks (12 metres), natural distribution just north half of north island.

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1889
Source:  Art Album NZ Flora
Author:  FEATON
Vol / Page:  55
Edition:
Quote:  HOHERIA POPULNEA (<I>A.Cunn.</I>) ... The `HOUI' or `WHAU-WHI'.- ... grows abundantly in both Islands  ... Owing to the chaste [snow-white] appearance of its flowers, it has not inaptly been termed by some the `New Zealand orange Blossom'. The inner bark is peculiar, and consists of layer upon layer of laced fibre, ...From this peculiarity it is called by the settlers the `Thousand Jacket', `lace-bark', or ... <I>Ibid.</I> 177 Houi [Maori name] .. Ribbon-wood [Settlers' name] .. Hoheria populnea .. Small tree

ribbonwood
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: names given to plants with a fibrous, lace-like inner bark espec. <i>Hoheria</i>, and <i>Plagianthus</i> spp =HOUHERE, =WILD CHERRY, =LACEBARK, =MANATU, =THOUSAND-JACKET
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: houhere, mountain ribbonwood, lowland ribbonwood, marsh ribbonwood, saltmarsh  ribbonwood et al
Pronunciation:
Notes: General; aka ribbon wood, ribbon-wood
Citations
Date:  12/10/1935
Source:  Christchurch Star-Sun
Author:
Vol / Page:  14
Edition:
Quote:  No imported tree surpasses in lavishness

of white blossom the New Zealand hoheria,

variously called ribbonwood and lacebark,

nor equals in beauty of shape or colour

its intricately dentate and translucent

green leaf.


Notes:

Date:  13/1/1863
Source:  Wellington Independent
Author:
Vol / Page:  3
Edition:
Quote:  The woods, it appears, which struck the most were the Rewarewara [sic], Mangias, mottled Kauri, Ribbonwood, Totara, Mairi, Tanekaea, Matai, Rimu, white tea-tree, and white Kauri, the latter being much in quest by ship builders.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1940
Source:  Plants of NZ
Author:  LAING & BLACKWELL
Vol / Page:  270
Edition:
Quote:   `Plants of both this [<I>Hoheria</I>] and of the next genus (<i>Plagianthus</i>), are popularly known as <i>Ribbonwoods</i>. The bast or inner bark is perforated by the medullary rays, and this gives to it a characteristic, ribbon-like appearance.'


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1869
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  1/III/31
Edition:
Quote:  ... in some cases, such as the Ribbon woods, plants of different genera are included in the one group..Ribbon Wood (<i>Plagianthus betulinus</i>). A very ornamental tree, especially when in flower, being covered with small white flowers... Ribbon Wood  (<i>Hoheria populnea </i>var.<i> angustifolia</i>)... Ribbon Wood (<i>Pennantia corymbosa</i>). This tree and the two former [<i>Plagianthus</i> and <i>Hoheria</i>], are often confounded, being very similar in general appearance, in soft, white, easily splitting, worthless wood; in the season, being covered with masses of small white fragrant flowers; ... Ribbon Wood (<i>Hoheria populnea</i> var. <i>crataegifolia</i>)... Ribbon Wood, or Lace-bark tree  (<i>Plagianthus Lyalli</i>) A very ornamental shrub tree, with large leaves and flowers. Common on the central ranges and west coast... Ribbonwood. <i>Plagianthus betulinus</i>, A. Cunn. <i>Ibid.</I> 40 Ribbonwood. <i>Hoheria populnea</i>, var. <i>angustifolia</i> ... Ribbonwood. <I>Pennantia Corymbosa </I>

Quote:  Its vernacular names are `Ribbon Wood' and `Lace Bark,' for when the bark is pulled off and cut into strips it reminds one of insertion lace.


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1906
Source:  Manual NZ Flora
Author:  CHEESEMAN
Vol / Page:  79
Edition:
Quote:  The Maoris apply the names <I>hoihere</I> or<I> houhere</I> to varieties [of<I> Hoheria populnea</I>] indifferently; the European settlers usually call all the forms `ribbon-wood' or `lacebark', names which are, unfortunately, also used for <I>Plagianthus betulinus</I> and <I>Gaya Lyallii. </I>


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1907
Source:  Plants of NZ
Author:  LAING & BLACKWELL
Vol / Page:  251
Edition:  1940  p. 264
Quote:  The varied names given by the Maoris in different districts to this plant [<I>Hoheria</I> spp.], are all said to spring from the same root. <I>Whau</I> [252] signifies <I>wrapped about, netted, - like lace</I>, and the treeis so called from the character of its inner bark. Thesettlers name it lace-bark, ribbon-wood, [1940 edn, no hyphens] or thousand-jacket.

Date:  0/0/1900
Source:  Canterbury Old & New
Author:
Vol / Page:  186
Edition:
Quote:  On the whole the beech forest is dark and gloomy, but here and there it may be lighted up by a tuft of scarlet or yellow native mistletoe  [fn Species of<i> Loranthus</i>.], or in spring by the gay garlands of white clematis; while in the more open places grows the beautiful ribbon-wood  [fn <i>Gaya ribifolia</i>, slightly different from the more western <i>Gaya lyallii</i>.], with a profusion of white flowers resembling pear-blossom.  <i>Ibid.</i> Masses of Ribbonwood will give a pale green hue to a portion of a hillside, ...




Notes:

Date:  0/0/1889
Source:  Art Album NZ Flora
Author:
Vol / Page:  54
Edition:
Quote:  On account of the fibrous nature of [<i>Plagianthus Lyallii's</i>] inner bark, it is popularly known in the Middle Island as one of the `Ribbon Wood' or `Lace Bark' trees, as is the <i>Hoheria populnea</i>, and its varieties in the Northern Island. <i>Ibid.</I> 178

Whauwhi [Maori name] .. Ribbon wood [Settlers' name] .. Plagianthus Lyallii .. Small tree `Ribbon-wood'.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1896
Source:  Pioneer Work in the Alps of NZ
Author:  HARPER
Vol / Page:  35
Edition:
Quote:  There is also the rata tree, the prince of firewoods, ... miki-miki, kamahi, or so-called red-birch, white and black birches (which are really beeches), the mountain broom, ribbon wood, broad leaf, totara, and many others, ... and always available in the Ranges [sc. Alps].


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Austral English
Author:  MORRIS
Vol / Page:  386
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Ribbonwood, n.</i> All species of <i>Plagianthus</i> and <i>Hoheria</i> are to the colonists Ribbonwood, especially <i>Plagianthus betulinus</i>, A. Cunn., and <i>Hoheria populnea</i>, A Cunn., the bark of which is used for cordage, and was once used for making a demulcent drink.  Alpine Ribbon-wood, <i>Plagianthus lyalli</i>. Hook. Other popular names are <i>Houhere, Houi</i> (Maori), <i>Lace-bark</i> (q.v.), and <i>Thousand-Jacket</i> (q.v.).

Date:  0/0/1906

Quote:  [<i>Plagianthus betulinus</i>, A.Cunn.] Ribbon-wood of Europeans; manatu of the Maoris.

Date:  0/0/1966
Source:  Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  History of Children's Play
Author:  SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page:  115
Edition:
Quote:  We sucked honey from various spring flowers, but the most prized was a low-growing and a very prickly native heather with flowers about half or three quarters of an inch long that grew on the stony plain. There were masses of it which we called rice-plant because its masses of sweet, juicy white berries spread out near the ground resembled polished rice in appearance. A plant that we called `wild birch' (because its leaves resembled birch leaves, I suppose) had red astringent berries that we enjoyed. It grew among the manuka scrub. ... (1900; Lower Moutere)

The name was probably first applied to the young kauri by the men of the Royal Navy in search of ships' spars.

rick-ma-tick
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  19/3/2003
Source:  Dominion Post
Author:
Vol / Page:  B7
Edition:
Quote:  Alison Nevill, of Dunedin, asks about the fascinating phrase "the whole rick-ma-tick". She says her Scottish grandmother employed a maid in the 40s who used it constantly, meaning something like "that's all there is to it". The maid came from Stirling, and the family always thought it was one of her home-town expressions, so when Alison got to New Zealand, she was surprised to hear it being used in the same context of finality. "The whole rick-ma-tick" has a long and honourable history as a Scottish version of "the whole kit and caboodle", an expression from the United States east coast that is widely understood here as an ornate alternative to "the whole lot".

Quote:  Like other experienced topdressing pilots he selected this ridge because it lay parallel to the sowing direction and he kept as close as possible to it thereby taking advantage of the added lift provided by the air rising off the ridge face. This procedure, known as "ridge riding", meant the aircraft was flown about five metres above the crest of the ridge and slightly to one side of it.

ridge-riding

Sense Number:

Quote:  The main road through the county is supposed to be constructed by the County Council, which is composed of representatives from the several ridings or districts forming the county, each riding electing a councillor every three years.


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1902
Source:  Settler's Handbook of NZ, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  142
Edition:
Quote:  When the nine provinces were abolished in 1876 the colony was divided for local government purposes into counties, regard being had to boundaries of existing road districts, and the counties were subdivided into ridings,  each riding being empowered to elect a certain number of members of the Council of the county. The ridings comprise one or more of the above three districts. They have no governing body - they are simply the electoral divisions of the county, and their maximum number is nine.

riffle
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: goldmining

Citations
Date:  0/0/1935
Source:  Gold Mining Year Book
Author:  BLYTH
Vol / Page:  11
Edition:
Quote:  Riffles: The diagonal, lengthwise or cross pieces or grooves in sluices which catch the heavier metallic particles allowing the clay and sand to pass. The value of the wash up is determined by the amount of gold or other metal caught in the riffles or other devices.


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1967
Source:  West Coast Gold Rushes
Author:  MAY
Vol / Page:  528
Edition:  1962
Quote:  RIFFLE OR RIPPLE: both terms were used for the grooves cut across the bottom of a sluice-box or for the much more common wooden bars fixed at right angles, obliquely, or lengthwise, to the bottom of a sluice. The `riffleboard' was detachable and formed a `false bottom'. `Riffle' was probably a Californian term; `ripple' seems to have been more usual on the goldfields of Australasia.


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1983
Source:  Gold Fossicker's Handbook
Author:  NOLAN
Vol / Page:  113
Edition:
Quote:  Riffle: shallow stretch of a stream or river, between pools, where the water runs fast and undulating. Also, probably by derivation, a raised wooden or metal crossbar in a sluice box.

rifleman

Date:  0/0/1888
Source:  Birds of New Zealand
Author:  BULLER
Vol / Page:  1/14
Edition:
Quote:  ... to say nothing of Korimako and Pitoitoi ... we never saw or heard the notes of either the Piopio, the Tieke, or the Hihi, all of which birds were at one time more numerous even than the Huia. The <i>Zosterops</i> was everywhere abundant, also the Grey Warbler and Rifleman, and ... we found the Tomtit comparatively plentiful; the Parakeet chased its mate through the tree-tops with sharp cries of `twenty-eight'; ... and among the tangle of the underwood the ever-present Flycatcher displayed its pretty fan-like tail.

Buller; Maori name, <i>Titipounamu</i>. See quotation. The name is sometimes applied also to the Rifle-bird [? in Australia] (q.v.).


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Merriam-Webster Third International
Author:
Vol / Page:  2030
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Riì.fle-man</i> (r&imacr.ì.f'l-man), <i>n. [Add.] </i>2. (Zoö.].) A small passerine bird of New Zealand (<i>Acanthidositta chloris</i>); so called from its green and bronze plumange, which is thought to resemble the uniform of the early British volunteer rifle corps. <i>Buller</i>.

Owing to the uncertainty regarding the species denoted by the term `wren' as used by the average observer, many records which may apply to this species have been left strictly alone. In the Wellington District the grey warbler  (<i>Maorigerygone igata</i> Quoy & Gaim.) is often referred to in popular parlance as the `native wren.'

Sense Number: 2
Definition: orig. SQUARE-RIGGER, a square-gin bottle; thence any large flagon or demijohn for holding esp. draught beer. (or, Havelock, vinegar) cf PETER @n2

Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]

Pronunciation:

Edition:
Quote:  I notice that the word `rigger' [in HNZD P.936] does not include the sense which used to be common, of a 1 litre JDKZ gin bottle filled at the pub with draft beer. I distinctly remember the notice at `His Lordships' a very scruffy tavern in St Asaph

St.Ch-ch `No jars or riggers filled after 5-45 pm.' This was deciphered by an elderly habitue for the innocent student.The word is apparently a contraction of the term `square rigger' used to describe a JDKZ bottle...  -->P: 5. `Quart of draught beer in square-faced gin bottle': Austr: ca 1918: (B 1942)

rigger

Citations
Date:  6/4/2004
Source:  Independent Herald (Wellington)
Author:
Vol / Page:  6
Edition:
Quote:  Many quality New Zealand beers are never bottled and are only available on tap from the brewery or a bottle store in 1.25 or 2 litre plastic bottles (called variously riggers, flagons or PETs depending on where you are from). I headed off to Regional Wines, and Spirits with a bag of empty riggers to sample some of their beers on tap... While beer in a rigger will keep fresh for a short time, ideally it should be consumed within a day or two of purchase.

right of way
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: -
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Merriam-Webster Third International
Author:
Vol / Page:  2034
Edition:
Quote:  <I>Way (w&amacr.), n. [Add.]

Right of way. [Add.] (b) (Pl., RIGHT OF WAYS.) A narrow street; a lane.

[Australia] </I> This use of the legal term in a concrete sense originated in Melbourne. In laying out the city, passages ten or twelve feet wide were left between the large rectangular lots. These passages ran from one broad street to another and were intended to afford a

<I>right of way</I> between the lots. Hence the term came to be applied to the passages themselves.

Vol / Page:  916
Edition:
Quote:  A form of assent, a token word in parting, a signal to proceed with the next sequence in the

operation, or, an acknowledgment that the speaker has been understood. .in 4;`Righto, then I'll leave Jack with you next trip, like you said.' 'I've got everything I wanted, I think. Righto, then, see you next week.' `Wait till I give the word you let the tray go. Righto! Now!'  `Righto! We're to leave any cleaning up till later, and load up and get back to the depot. O.K....'


Notes:  (1962-63)1974 Syder and Hodgetts Aust. and NZ English [TS] 916

right-whale porpoise
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1922
Source:  NZ Journal of Science & Technology
Author:
Vol / Page:  5/140
Edition:
Quote:   The right-whale porpoise (<i>Lissodelphis peroni</i>) can be at once recognized by the absence of a dorsal fin. It possesses a distinct beak, and about 44 pairs of small pointed teeth. The colouring is distinctive: the back is black, and this colour is sharply marked off from the under-parts, which are white, the line between the two passing above the tail, flippers, and snout.
Notes:   (Oliver)

Vol / Page:  331
Edition:
Quote:  Rill stope: A filled stope worked on a 45-degree angle from one end progressively towards the other. It had the advantage that less shovelling of both quartz and filling was required and the material could be quickly and easily placed on the rill.
Notes:

rilling
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: [soil erosion] the formation of small gullies in cultivated hillsides.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1961
Source:  Agriculture
Author:  CONNELL & HADFIELD
Vol / Page:  251
Edition:
Quote:  On the more gently sloping land, especially where it is cultivated, puddle erosion, the loss of fine particles in muddy water run-off, and rilling, small gullies in cultivated hillsides, occur.
Notes:

rimrod rock

Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: rock, of an extremely hard type.


Origin: [none]
Register:

Domain: Rural
Region: [none]

Vol / Page:  159

Quote:  The soil is of a pumice formation, running into clay and papa on the lower country where there are outcrops of rimrod rock.
Notes:

rimu
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: an important native timber tree, especially prized for furniture manufacture. Also called red pine.
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: RED-PINE (Cook's <i>Spruce</i>) a forest tree, and its timber: see also IMOU  Rimu is used in North Island, and in Nelson and Marlborough and  Westland. <i>Red-pine</i> has been used chiefly in Central Otago (for the tree) and Southland, and (for the timber) in Otago and Canterbury. <i>Rimu</i>  seems to be replacing <i>Red-pine</i> as a tree-name even in the Southern South Island. Rimu is universally known, but not universally used. Morris (1896) remarks that <i>Rimu</i> generally used in North Island, <i>Red-pine</i> more generally in the South.
Citations
Date:  14/10/1882
Source:  Feilding Star
Author:
Vol / Page:  1
Edition:
Quote:  Totara, Rimu, Matai, and White Pine supplied in any quantities.

Source:  Otago Witness
Author:
Vol / Page:  37

Quote:  FELLING A GIANT RIMU.

Date:  17/7/1896

Author:
Vol / Page:  h-24
Edition:
Quote:  The Committee recommends the disuse of the terms `red-pine', `white-pine', and `black-pine', in favour of rimu, kahikatea and matai, in order to prevent their being confused with timbers having similar names in Europe
Notes:  ) Interim Report No.3 (i) of Timber Conference Appendix Journals H.24

Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  spg remo ... the prevailing species of trees are remo [rimu], totara, and tall manuka, all indicative of inferior soil.... The bush-like woods on the east side are of white birch, likewise no recommendation of the soil, but the chief objection to the district is, that the prairie soil affords scarcely any food for cattle ... it grows only the wiry tree grass [tussock] ... and  Phormium tenax [flax], no aniseed, perennial groundsel, or milk thistle, and very little couch grass.


Notes:  1844 Aug 16 Tuckett's Diary in 1898 Hocken contributions 223-224

ring

Sense Number:
Definition: to ringbark
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]

See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1875
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  7/186
Edition:
Quote:  During these two months, July and August, let them `ring' the trees, that is cut out a ring of bark and sap 3 or 4 inches wide round all the trees they intend to cut down or `fall' during the next 12 months.
Notes:  (Firth)

Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Austral English
Author:  MORRIS
Vol / Page:  388
Edition:
Quote:  Ring, v. (1) To cut the bark of a tree round the trunk so as to kill it. The word is common in the same sense in English forestry and horticulture, and only seems Australasian from its more frequent use, owing to the widespead practice of clearing the primeval forests and generally destroying trees. `Ringed' is the correct past participle, but `rung' is now

commonly used. [1846] ... (2) to make cattle move in a circle. [1874] ... (3) To move round in a circle [1884] ...  (4) To make the top score at a shearing-shed.' See Ringer.


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1929
Source:  Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.
Author:
Vol / Page:  10
Edition:
Quote:   ring v.t. to kill a tree by cutting the bark round the trunk; to make cattle move in a circle;-v.i. to move in a circle, as cattle or birds; to win in a sheep-shearing contest. -ring'er n. the man who shears most sheep in a day. - ring'-bark v.t. to ring a tree.-ring'-neck n. a newly arrived immigrant, esp. from England; a jackaroo

ring
Homonym Number:  3

Date:  0/0/1898

Author:  MORRIS
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:
Notes:  see @v1 above

Date:  0/0/1933
Source:  Press, The
Author:  ACLAND
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  Merino sheep on the flat, especially when coming to a gate, are apt to circle. The centre of the mob may stand still, or move slowly forward; but the outside sheep gallop round and round them. This is  called ringing. It is annoying to see the sheep racing past the gate instead of going through it, but the habit may be turned to the shepherd's advantage. By starting the sheep on one side ringing the reverse way, two streams of sheep can be made to meet at the gate, and carry one another through.


Notes:

ring

Sense Number:

was the roar, as we all rushed in for our own, and anybody else's one could get.

ring bark
Homonym Number:
Word Class: verb
Sense Number:
Definition: to cut away a ring of bark from around a trunk in order to kill a tree
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: aka ring-bark, ringbark
Citations
Date:  22/5/1875
Source:  Daily Southern Cross
Author:
Vol / Page:  4
Edition:
Quote:  THE WEEKLY NEWS ..

CONTENTS FOR THIS WEEK..

To Ring-bark Trees ...
Notes:

Date:  27/7/1904
Source:  Tuapeka Times
Author:
Vol / Page:  1
Edition:
Quote:  The idea is to ringbark the trees and bore through the trunk with an augur a couple of holes which are filled with a composition and plugged. The composition soaks into the wood, rots it, and causes it to become inflammable. In about eight or ten months a match is applied, and the tree falls, the stump and roots which have become soaked with the mixture, being burned right out.
Notes:

Date:  20/2/1893
Source:  Hawke's Bay Herald
Author:
Vol / Page:  4
Edition:
Quote:  The dead tree by the gas works has been cut down, and the gentleman who ring-barked it for impeding his zig-zag progress can now absorb his whisky with a comparatively easy mind.
Notes:

Date:  6/4/1887
Source:  Tuapeka Times
Author:
Vol / Page:  2
Edition:
Quote:  Trees thus treated invariably die out as if ring barked, and hitherto we have heard of no remedy which has been successful in bringing them back to life by renewing the lost skin.

Author:  MacDONALD
Vol / Page:  204

Edition:

Date:  0/0/1941
Source:  Numismatic History of NZ
Author:  SUTHERLAND
Vol / Page:  66
Edition:
Quote:  In New South Wales, in 1813, this difficulty [of shortage of coin] became so acute that Governor

Macquarie, in an effort to check the outflow of Spanish dollars, then the main circulating medium, caused the centres of these coins to be struck out, the centre-piece (about the size of a shilling) being stamped NEW SOUTH WALES, 1813, around a central crown, and on the other side FIFTEEN PENCE, the remainder or `ring' part of the dollar being impressed around the new

inner rim with NEW SOUTH WALES, 1813 on one side, and FIVE SHILLINGS on the other. ... [67] 3,008 Dollars (mainly Holey or Ring Dollars) [pounds] 752 0 0/ 725 Dumps (centres of Spanish Dollars) 45 6 3

Notes:

ringanui
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a groundwater crustacean
Origin: Maori
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: The name <i>Ringanui</i> is derived from the Maori words <i>ringa</i> (hand) and <i>nui</i> (big) in reference to the very large gnathopod 1 characteristic of this genus.  **The name <i>toonuiiti</i> is derived from Maori <i>toonui</i> (thumb) and <i>iti</i> (little) and refers to the smaller robust seta defining the proximal end of the gnathopod 1 palm...  **The name <i>koonuiroa</i> is derived from Maori <i>koonui</i> (thumb) and <i>roa</i> (long) and refers to the very large robust seta defining the proximal end of the gnathopod 1 palm...

Citations
Date:  0/0/2006
Source:  Internet - see Notes
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  The new genus, Ringanui, is a significant step in resolving this

confusion. Ringanui differs from Paraleptamphopus on several characters and is most easily

recognised by diverse gnathopods, the first of which is enlarged relative to gnathopod 2. The two

species are described and illustrated in detail. They differ in size and gnathopod characteristics, but

other differences are small. Ringanui koonuiroa is the smaller species and is most easily recognised

by the single, very long robust seta defining the palm of gnathopod 1. The second species, R.

toonuiiti, is the larger, but its palmar defining spine is relatively short.
Notes:  http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2006f/z01148p025f.pdf Accessed on 14/03 2006

Notes:

Date:  16/9/1889
Source:  Wanganui Herald
Author:
Vol / Page:  2
Edition:
Quote:  At the native meeting up the river the diversity of religions caused some discussion. There are four religions altogether, Protestant (Church of England), Catholic, Salvation Army, and Te Kooti's religion (Ringatu). The latter is a bugbear to some of the natives, particularly the Catholics, but the meeting decided on freetrade in this matter, the main argument being that as Englishmen had hundreds of religions there was no reason why the Maoris should not have at least four. .. The term Ringatu is, we understand, derived from the fact that in place of saying "Amen," as usual in other services, they say "Glory."
Notes:

Date:  4/10/2003
Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page:  29
Edition:
Quote:  The 1870-72 Urewera expeditions were driven by a vengeful Colonial Government (also known as the Kawanatanga), desperate to track down and destroy Te Kooti Arikirangi Te Turuki and his Ringatu guerilla force then regrouping within the boundaries of the Tuhoe tribe's forested rohe.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1905

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1989
Source:  NZ English Newsletter
Author:
Vol / Page:  3/27
Edition:
Quote:  ringer: The fastest shearer in the shed over the period of shearing, and different from a `gun'. The ringer could be the best of several gun shearers in the same shed, but he could also be a ringer in a weak team and not even be a gun. A possible origin of the term can be found under `quoits' but others are that the ringer `runs rings round the rest' and the ringer in Yorkshire dialect means anyone superlatively good.

The fastest shearer on the board. He usually shears on the first stand next to the wool table. Any rival shearer must shear a bigger tally for three consecutive days before he can take the ringer's stand.

Notes:

ringer
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: (marbles term)
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1953
Source:  Unorganized Games
Author:  SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page:  2/770
Edition:
Quote:  It is important to distinguish these `Action-Terms' of marbles from the innumerable merely descriptive marble terms which have no effect on the course of the action - terms such as Ringer, In, Smug, Dead Stick, Skun, Skinned, Sported off, Scat, Cannons, Dubs, Kills, Funs, Keeps, Pink.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1972
Source:  Folkgames of Children
Author:  SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page:  175
Edition:
Quote:  Some of the typical terms used in marbles referred to the act of shooting and the movement of the marbles. Those related to ways of shooting marbles were cribbing, firsts, fudging, funks, funnicks, funnigans, flunks, forces, knee-high, knuckle-down-stiff, knuckles, and lasts. Terms connected with the movement of the marbles were: cannons, clears, dead-stick, double-hits,

fires, funs, gees, haystacks, in smug, keeps, kills, kisses, lay-ups, manyes, ones, pink, ringer, rolls, scat, screws, skinned, skun, spiders, sported-off, stays, stops, tracks, throughs.

<I>Ibid.</I> 176 [Waitara, Taranaki, 1899: reference, game of Little Ring] Many heated arguments arose as to who said `everythings' or `nothings' first. If a player's `taw' touched a marble and lay alongside it, the others would shout `knuckle down' just before his turn. ... `Knuckle down' meant that the player had to hold his taw close to the marble attacked and fire it in that very inconvenient position. ... When a boy lost all his marbles at play he was `scat' [?related to skint ?HWO] . ... A `ringer' was a taw which, when fired at the commencement of the game, lodged in the track of the ring itself; that, and knocking a marble out when he `fired' were the perfect shots. ... To fire a shot while holding the hand nearer to the ring than where the taw had lain, was to `funk', an unforgiveable crime.


Notes:

ringer
Homonym Number:  2
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a throw that rings the spike (?or object at hoopla)
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: (quoits)
Citations
Date:  0/0/1907
Source:  Elixir of Life
Author:  SATCHELL
Vol / Page:  190
Edition:
Quote:  The click of quoits as someone threw a ringer.


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1989
Source:  NZ English Newsletter
Author:
Vol / Page:  3/26
Edition:
Quote:  quoits: In the early days when men were isolated at the sheds, quoits was a popular game. Iron rings or old horse shoes were used and the one who beat the rest was the `ringer'. This term `ringer', and `good iron' could have drifted into the shed where it is still used today.


Notes:  (Wallace Shearing Glossary)



ringer

Edition:
Quote:  POLICE believe several gangs of car ringers are active in Christchurch. They use identification plates and papers from wrecks to disguise stolen vehicles before resale....The ringers buy a late-model wreck written off by an insurance company and steal a similar car. The identification plates are then changed over and the stolen vehicle is sold as a rebuilt wreck.

Date:  0/0/1888
Source:  Birds of New Zealand
Author:  BULLER
Vol / Page:  1/81
Edition:
Quote:  The natives distinguish the bird as Tau-hou (which means stranger), or Kanohi-mowhiti (which may be interpreted as spectacle-eye or ring-eye). It is also called Poporoke and Iringatu, names suggested by its accidental or periodical occurrence. <i>Ibid.</I> 1/82 By the settlers it [sc  Zosterops] has been variously designated as Ring-eye, Wax-eye, White-eye, or Silver-eye, in allusion to the beautiful circlet of satiny-white feathers which surrounds the eyes; and quite as commonly as the `Blight-bird', or `Winter Migrant'.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Austral English
Author:  MORRIS
Vol / Page:  389
Edition:
Quote:  Ring-eye, n.  one of the many names for the birds of the genus <I>Zosterops </I>(q.v.).
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1946
Source:  Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:  ANDERSON
Vol / Page:  55/159
Edition:
Quote:  <I>tauhou</I>, a wandering bird (Zosterops halmaturina), blight-bird; twinkie; button-eye; wax-eye; ring-eye. Tauhou means stranger and this name was given by the Maori when the bird appeared, in 1856, in the central part of New Zealand, gradually spreading north and south till the islands were occupied. It is an Australian bird, and was blown across the Tasman sea

in the year mentioned.

Date:  0/0/1953
Source:  Story of the Kauri, The
Author:  REED
Vol / Page:  157
Edition:
Quote:  Deeper scarves were cut out of all Leaning trees to prevent them from splitting up. After sawing to a certain depth ..... each man alternately cut round his side of the tree almost to the front scarf. The adoption of this plan, known as `ringing', caused the wood to break clean when falling.

Quote:  The Rip (Cook Strait) Terawhiti rip

The boat [Tamahine c1941] always seemed to head for that notorious stretch of water known as `the rip', and all the chairs ... anchored with chains would turn over, while a nurse in white would move about among the green passengers with much-needed strawberry boxes.  -->OED 1. commotion of seas caused by opposing currents or by a rapid current passing over an ... 1836,

1860, 1875 2. tidal wave or current 1903; CC Ransom =US riptide, rip current

Quote:  The term [tide-rip] is well-known in New Zealand and especially in Melbourne; I never heard it used in England although I am informed they exist in the Portland firth, and ... near Weymouth. A Tide-rip is caused by a current setting in a certain direction after a gale of wind over perhaps an under surface.

Date:  0/0/1939
Source:  First White Boy Born in Otago
Author:  BEATTIE
Vol / Page:  172
Edition:

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1967
Source:  West Coast Gold Rushes
Author:  MAY
Vol / Page:  528
Edition:  1962
Quote:  RIFFLE OR RIPPLE: both terms were used for the grooves cut across the bottom of a sluice-box or for the much more common wooden bars fixed at right angles, obliquely, or lengthwise, to the bottom of a sluice. The `riffleboard' was detachable and formed a `false bottom'. `Riffle' was probably a Californian term; `ripple' seems to have been more usual on the goldfields of Australasia.


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1903
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  35/403
Edition:
Quote:  Mr. William Beetham ... in Nelson, mentioned the trouble ... occasioned at the erpiodical `clean-up' by the presence of ... lead which collected in the ripples with the gold.

Date:  12/4/1894
Source:  Otago Witness
Author:
Vol / Page:  15
Edition:
Quote:  There is a slight fall between each roller, on which are placed copper ripple plates, so that whatever gold is liberated by the crushing of the first roller has a chance to get amalgamated on the first copper ripples, and so with the second chamber, where the material passes through a rough grating before entering the third or last chamber, where it is retained until fine enough to go through a 240 punched grating, after which it is passed over the final copper ripples.

Date:  0/0/1975

Vol / Page:  18
Edition:
Quote:  We got a `fiery stick' from some Maoris ... who were waiting for a

`Goashore' of `Ripiri' to cool ... The mess was in time cool enough, when they all surrounded the great pot, some with pewter spoons, ... but most with shells from the beach ... .


Notes:  c1920s Eliza McKenzie in Outlook in 1975 Knight Poyntzfield 18 [reference Wellington 1850s]



Date:  0/0/1966
Source:  Kapiti Coast
Author:  CARKEEK
Vol / Page:  52
Edition:
Quote:  Hadfield in his 1839 diary mentions eating a meal which included boiled flour. This is probably the same food which became known to the Maoris later as riripi. It consisted of flour and water, with sugar [53] to sweeten, boiled and served up as a kind of porridge. In the early whaling days it was often served up to a whole village community from a canoe set up like a trough from which the villagers scooped their requirements in large bowls or paua shells. Many of the Ngati Raukawa of Otaki have vivid recollections of having eaten riripi in their childhood.

The Matata has four long and four short tail feathers,  similar in texture to those of the Kiwi.

rise
Homonym Number:  2
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: an upward shaft
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1961
Source:  Friends in Chains
Author:  HENDERSON
Vol / Page:  188
Edition:
Quote:
Notes:  c1900-1920 A Teamster's Glossary in 1961 Henderson Friends In Chains 188



Date:  0/0/1935
Source:  Gold Mining Year Book
Author:  BLYTH
Vol / Page:  11
Edition:
Quote:  Rise: Rising on the ore body.  RISE: Quartz-mining term for working in or driving a shaft upwards.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1978
Source:  Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary)
Author:  McARA
Vol / Page:  331
Edition:
Quote:  Rise: A timbered excavation constructed by working upwards, using upper holes. Rising was done on the three-compartment system, that is with a ladderway on one end and a return airway on the other, with a `box' in the centre. This box was kept filled with ore and used to stand on while drilling the roof, the level of the ore being maintained by, drawing off the surplus ore through a chute at the bottom of the box. Rises were about 9 ft by 4 ft in section and might reach from one level to the next (about 150 ft), or to a sublevel, or from a stope to the level above.

Date:  0/0/1838

Quote:  The erect erito [e-acute], and other umbelliferous palm-[68]trees wave their broad leaves proudly amid the varied foliage of the surrounding trees. <i>Ibid.</I> 1/105 There is scarcely a more splendid sight to behold than a New Zealand forest. In the one we now entered, we did not perceive any kouri, or yellow pine-trees; but the totara [a's-acute], or red pine, grew in vast abundance. ... The rito, and innumerable other palm-trees, were in great quantity.  <i>Ibid.</I>

1/143  In addition to the fare set before me at supper, a quantity of  rito, or hearts of the palm-tree, were also included. This vegetable, which is eaten uncooked, makes a salad unequalled for its excellent flavour, and is held in much esteem by the people.  <i>Ibid.</I>

1/287 rito The heart of the delicious palms, called E' Rito, is highly esteemed. The  korou, which the branches of another of these umbelliferous trees afford is equally prized, together with the saccharine roots of the ti, cabbage-tree.
Notes:

river
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: ?mainly Auckland cf CREEK
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: [see also ?Eaddy GRAVEYARD (?Kaipara)] -->R. Mason notes: in Auckland Province narrow harbours or arms of harbours, mostly on the west coast are often called rivers, and were so named on older maps and in writings. They are in fact formed by the drowning of river systems. [nf in this sense OED, EDD, W3] -->On old maps: The Whangape River, The Herekino River, The Hokianga River; on present-day maps, The Waiuku River. At the present time [1957] the local inhabitants refer to the Hokianga Harbour as `the river', as do the people of Herekino to the Herekino harbour. Jane mander's novel  The Story of a New Zealand River refers to the Kaipara harbour, I understand. Various arms of kaipara and Hokianga are still named `rivers' on present maps. In Waitemata Harbour, the Whau River; and other branches also rivers.
Citations

Notes:

river
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number: 2
Definition: as in general English: but in early uses (a) note that the epithet freshwater is often prefixed; and (b) note the contrasting British usage (and possibly Australian), e.g. the River Thames, the River Murray, with NZ, the Thames River

river flat
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: [used elsewhere, but widely used and significant in New Zealand's horticulture, agriculture, pastoralism, and viticulture] a level area of land formed from the course of a river.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]

Vol / Page:  7/368
Edition:
Quote:  The Black or River Flounder of New Zealand (<i>Rhombosolea retiaria</i>). The river-flounder is one of the common edible fishes of Wellington. Though not so common as either the yellow or sand flounder, it is much in demand as the chief delicacy among all species of flat fish eaten by the New Zealand public.
Notes:  (Phillipps)

Date:  0/0/1938
Source:  TrRSNZ
Author:
Vol / Page:  68/408
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Rhombosolea retiaria</i> Hutton. River flounder (black flounder).
Notes:  Graham Fishes of Otago Harbour

Source:  NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide

Date:  0/0/1967
Source:  Marine Fishes
Author:  MORELAND
Vol / Page:  32
Edition:
Quote:  BLACK FLOUNDER [<i>Rhombosolea retiaria</i>] ... River flounder and mud flounder are widely used alternative names.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1956
Source:  NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author:  GRAHAM
Vol / Page:  204
Edition:  2nd
Quote:  NEW ZEALAND BLACK FLOUNDER or RIVER FLOUNDER (PATIKI-MOHOAO)

<i>Rhombosolea (Adamsoma) retiaria adams</i> Whitley and Phillipps/ It is known to fishermen and those in the fishing industry as the River Flounder as it is caught mostly inside or near the mouths of rivers and enters lakes where it lives chiefly among weeds. To some it is known as the Maori Flounder. I have helped to catch these fish in various rivers in New Zealand, Both in the North and South Islands, from the Bay of Islands, Bay of Plenty, Canterbury and Otago.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1966
Source:  Sea Anglers' Guide
Author:  DOOGUE & MORELAND
Vol / Page:  215
Edition:
Quote:  BLACK FLOUNDER ...   <i>Other names: Rhombosolea retiaria</i>; mud flounder, river flounder, estuary flonder; patiki-mahoao (Maori).
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  Fisherman's Bible
Author:  WILSON
Vol / Page:  72
Edition:
Quote:  FLOUNDER, BLACK More sole-like in shape than his cousin flounders this fellow also has small, brick-red spots on his back and has the ability - unlike the other flatfish - of being able to live in pure, fresh water. Other names are `River Flounder' and `Mud or Freshwater Flounder'.


Notes:

Date:  23/7/1986
Source:  Codes for Species in NZ Waters
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  [species name] black flounder .. [scientific name]  <i>Rhombosolea retiaria</i> .. [other name(s)] blacks, freshwater flounder, river flounder


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1986
Source:  NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author:
Vol / Page:  144
Edition:
Quote:  Black flounder <i>Rhombosolea retiaria</i> Restricted to New Zealand. Alternative names include river flounder, freshwater flounder, or estuary flounder, derived from its habitat.
Notes:

Date:  0/7/1921
Source:  NZ Journal of Science & Technology
Author:  PHILLIPPS
Vol / Page:  IV/122
Edition:
Quote:  <i>RHOMBOSOLEA RETIARIA</i> Hutton. Black Flounder; Patiki-mohoao. This species, known generally as `river-flounder,' is occasionally taken in the sea. Common in the estuaries of most large rivers, and often taken many miles inland.


Notes:  Phillipps Notes on the Edible Fishes

They covered a tremendous amount of country, all hard going, and the River Gang was widely known.

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  Fisherman's Bible
Author:  WILSON
Vol / Page:  118
Edition:
Quote:  Most gurnards are brownish-red but larger specimens are often bright red on top and white below. The Stargazer is sometimes known as the Mud Gurnad, River Gurnard or Mud-Grubber Gurnard but is in fact no relation. Similarly the Sea Perch is sometimes called a Rock Gurnard - ..

. <I>Ibid.</I> 197 RIVER GURNARD:  see <i>Spotted Stargazer </i> <I>Ibid.</I> 208

STARGAZER A distinctive estaurine fish which spends most of its life buried in mud up to the eyes. ... Comes in two varieties - the Common Stargazer and his tubbier cousin the Spotted Stargazer. ... Other names are River Gurnard, Mud Gurnard, Flathead Gurnard and Mud Grubber


Notes:

Maori offender who sincerely believed

that to be a Maori was to be

automatically dumber; that to succeed

even, in our society, it is necessary to

neglect or even forget taha Maori. To

become a riwai, a potato, dark outside,

white inside.

road weed
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: wireweed
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1926
Source:  Weeds of New Zealand
Author:  HIL;GENDORF
Vol / Page:  61
Edition:  1967
Quote:  WIREWEED (<i>Polygonum aviculare</i>), also called road weed, mat weed, knot grass, [pig weed,] and hog weed, is common in

cultivated land all over the country. It is an annual, with stems up to 2ft. in length trailing over the ground. The stems have swollen nodes (`knot grass') and are very tough (`wireweed').


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1969
Source:  Standard Common Names for Weeds
Author:
Vol / Page:  64
Edition:
Quote:  road weed [=] wireweed [s]

Date:  0/0/1958
Source:  Making of a New Zealander, The
Author:  MULGAN
Vol / Page:  17
Edition:
Quote:  Often settlers went right out into the wilds and had to wait long for reasonably good communications. This partly explains the importance of the `roads and bridges member' in the New Zealand Parliament, a term that has well-nigh disappeared. One might laugh at him and deplore his preoccupation with local matters, but road or bridge could be life or death to an outback settler. The central Government was the main source of bounty, so grants were continually asked for.

Notes:

Roaring Meg
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a common name from gold-digging and coaching days for swift, rapid-rising creeks or small rivers (cf CRYING JENNY, GENTLE ANNIE) The first is very small, and in a dry season merely drips from the road


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: ca 1951 a mountain stream in Tararuas (NCC Small) 1955 Dec 24 Illustrated London News 1113 [caption] -->R. Mason notes of the creek name that the following may have some bearing on the original naming. A model of Londonderry's famous gun `Roaring Meg': in silver on an oak stand, presented to Sir Winston Churchill when he became freeman of Londonderry. cf OED (1575) a huge cannon etc.; (cf Illustr London News. 1955 Dec 24 p1113) (1632) kind of top; (1811) (Geol) Trans. Geol Soc. This structure of clay .... goes by the name of shaggy metal, and the fresh water which makes its way through the pores has the expressive appellation of Roaring Meg.; W3 only common usage  (cf. Roaring (adj) 1848. boisterous; (of health) exuberant)

Date:  0/0/1874
Source:  George Washington Pratt
Author:  PYKE
Vol / Page:  1,3
Edition:
Quote:  By the side of `Roaring Meg' ... [3] The mountain torrent where to allusion has been made was the stream named by surveyors as the `Kirtleburn', but which is best known by the fantastic appellation conferred on it by the miners - `Roaring Meg' There are three creeks in succession on this line of road - tributaries of the Kawarau River. ocks, and is called `Crying Jenny' The second, which tumbles down from the mountains impetuously and with great noise, is `Roaring Meg' The third, being a sluggish stream, has received, by popular assent, the designation of `Gentle Annie'

A little below this bridge we crossed a Beautiful Mountain Torrent call'd Roaring Mag, and not inaptly ...

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1943
Source:  Pure Gold
Author:  HISLOP
Vol / Page:  20
Edition:
Quote:  There are now several bonnie burns coming down the mountain sides to the river, the largest of which are the famous Roaring Meg and Gentle Annie; and a visitor ... may wash his colours of gold from almost anywhere while his wee wife boils the billy. <i>Ibid.</i> 53  ... Roxburgh and Cromwell are well behind, and I slow down ... to

enjoy the sight of the water gushing from the spillway of the newly-erected power station at the Roaring Meg corner of the [Kawarau] Gorge. This heavy stream, which breaks so suddenly on a stranger from its very rough surroundings, got its name (according to early-day tradition) from the fact that Meg, one of the two girls on their way to a dancing saloon at Arrow, created such a fuss at crossing this turbulent water that vibrations of her voice loosened rocks on the mountain side to add still further to the roaring of stream and of Meg herself. There are different versions concerning the naming of this stream, and maybe some of this one is my own. ... A few miles

further on the next stream to be crossed is the Gentle Annie, called after Meg's pal, who no doubt was a much quieter type of tourist than Meg herself.




Notes:

Date:  0/0/1959
Source:  Tararua
Author:
Vol / Page:  13/49
Edition:
Quote:
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1988
Source:  Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A
Author:  McGILKL
Vol / Page:  93
Edition:
Quote:  Roaring Meg a raging river, perhaps near a Gebtle Annie mountain; possibly after legendary Irish landlady Maggie (Mag or Meg) Brennan of the Queenstown area who allegedly bellowed at customers and threw stroppy clients in the nearby creek; ref. James McNeish's  Tavern in the Town; also the name of a Londonderry gun.

roaring up
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a severe reprimand
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: ca 1951 Miss G. Hall: (Letter) [? Central Otago] `A roaring up': a severe talking to, in the disciplinary sense: such as `I gave him a number one roaring up and sent him down the road (q.v.)'  cf Part. Roar up: Speak abusively to; shout at Lower classes': from ca 1905 F and G; AC 1919

robin
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a) any of various small, plump, European birds with an orange breast. b) any of various similar but unrelated Australian birds, with scarlet or pink breasts. c) any of three similar but unrelated New Zealand birds. Also called toutouwai, katuhituhi. [AND name 1823] Miro australis, BUSH ROBIN, NATIVE ROBIN, NEW ZEALAND ROBIN, TOUTOUWAI 1. simplex  (distinguish North Island and South Island Robins, and deal with them here: but only if epithet in text: give defin. that covers both races]

Quote:  The lark is nearly identical and the quail is the same - the hawk the same - the robin has its counterpart here in a bird with a slate coloured head and throat with a canary coloured breast, to all intents and purposes it is a robin for all that; ...
Notes:

Date:  0/4/1861
Source:  Diary
Author:  BUTLER
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:   - It is Sunday. We rose later than usual. There are five men sleeping in the hut. I sleep in a bunk on one side of the fire, Mr. Haast ... sleeps upon the opposite one; my bullock-driver and hut-keeper have two bunks at the far end of the hut, along the wall; ... The usual mutton and bread for breakfast with a pudding made of flour and water baked in the camp-oven after a joint of meat - Yorkshire pudding, but without eggs. While we were at breakfast, a robin perched on the table and sat there a good while pecking at the sugar.
Notes:  1861 April Butler's Note in 1919 Jones Samuel Butler - A Memoir 1/87 April, 1861



Date:  13/4/1864
Source:  Diary
Author:  BARRINGTON
Vol / Page:
Edition:

The New Zealand species are -  -->Chatham Island Robin - Miro traversi, Buller. North Island R. - M. australis, Sparrm.  -->South Island R. - M. albifrons, Gmel.  -->[NZ Dates 1866 Lady B. S. L; 1872 Domett]

rock cod
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number: 3
Definition: a dark purplish-brown morid cod of coastal reefs. Also called Cloudy Bay cod, kelp cod, and (inappropriately) southern hake.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]

Notes:  1841 Mar 24 Weekes Jnl in 1940 Establishment of New Plymouth 39



Date:  0/0/1925
Source:  NZ Journal of Science & Technology
Author:
Vol / Page:  7/369
Edition:
Quote:  A specimen of this rather rare fish [<I>Physiculus (Lotella) rhacinus</I> (Forster)] was captured off Cape Saunders early in 1924, and kept in captivity for several months. Before its death my curiosity was aroused by one of the staff calling it a `rock-cod' and stating that that was the name used in the north even where the `blue-cod' <I>Parapercis colias</I> was also caught.
Notes:  (Young)

Date:  0/0/1927
Source:  Bibliography of NZ Fishes

Vol / Page:  68/405

Quote:  <I>Lotella rhacinus</I> (Forster). Rock cod.
Notes:  Graham Fishes of Otago Harbour

Date:  0/0/1956
Source:  NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author:  GRAHAM
Vol / Page:  172
Edition:
Quote:  ROCK COD or SOUTHERN HAKE <I>Lotella rhacina</I> (Bloch and Schneider) Up to 1891 this fish was universally known to scientists and fishermen as Hake, then for some unknown reason E. R. Waite (<I>Records of the Canterbury Museum</I>, Vol. 1, No. 3) transferred the name Hake to <I>Merluccius gayi</I>, with Whiting as a second alternative common name. ... The most common name among Otago fishermen was Rock Cod, because this fish favours a rocky habitat.
Notes:

Author:  DOOGUE & MORELAND

There are snappers (schnapper), mullet, bream, soles, eels, and a great quantity of cockles, and some rock oysters. There is likewise abundance of lobsters, or a fish between a lobster and a craw-fish.

Foveaux Strait) are taken commercially. Our three main oysters are <i>Ostrea hefferdi</i> (southern rock oyster), <i>O. sinuata</i> (mud oyster, ... ), and <i>Saxostrea glomerata</i> (northern rock oyster).

Quote:  Post rammer, four way tilt, side shift, collapsible mast, rock spike, had little work, $10,500 + GST.
Notes:

rock trout
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: Galaxias alepidotus, a freshwater fish, often a kokopu, one of a number of misnamed `trout'.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: kokopu
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  4/10/1930
Source:  Evening Post
Author:
Vol / Page:  7
Edition:
Quote:  It is interesting to note that this fish belongs to the same family (Galaxiidae) as the common kokopo, or New Zealand rock trout, and the inanga (the parent of the New Zealand whitebait), but has been placed in a separate genus (Neochanna) on account of the absence of the paired ventral fins, which characteristic occurs, on the contrary, in all species of the genus Galaxias.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1843
Source:  New Zealand (various authors/titles)
Author:  DIEFFENBACH
Vol / Page:  2/219
Edition:
Quote:  61. <i>Galaxias alepidotus.</i> - Cuv., ... Named by the natives of Dusky Bay `He-para,' and by Cook's sailors `Rock-trout.' [Williams 262 <i>Para</i> a fresh-water fish similar to a <i>ko[o]kopu.] </I>
Notes:  1842 Gray's Fauna (Richardson's Fish) in 1843 Dieffenbach NZ 2/219

Date:  0/0/1903

Author:
Vol / Page:  35/317

Quote:  Also, the settlers in at least some parts of New Zealand have dignified the larger kinds [of Galaxias spp, kokopu] with the name of `trout' or `rock-trout'
Notes:  (Hector)

Date:  0/0/1945
Source:  Maori Place-Names of Canterbury
Author:  BEATTIE
Vol / Page:  63
Edition:
Quote:  Panako - The collector [sc Beattie] asked a Maori about this fish, as it was a new name to him, and received the reply: `The panako is the rock trout, and is nearly extinct. It looks like the kokopara in shape, but it is black in colour.'
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1956
Source:  NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author:  GRAHAM
Vol / Page:  118
Edition:
Quote:  MINNOW or WHITEBAIT (INANGA) <i>Austrocobitis attenuatus </i>(Jenyns) ... For a long time it has been known to the Maori and to Europeans that our New Zealand Whitebait is the young of a native freshwater fish commonly known as Minnow, or Inanga or Hiwi to the Maori, and erroneously called a Trout. ... The early settlers called it Maori Trout, Native Trout, Rock Trout and Minnow. But it is not a Trout. Nor is it a Minnow, through it resembles the English freshwater Minnow. While the name Trout is not correct, it is and will always be known as such by farmers and naturalists. In the Bay of Plenty, Whitebait is known to the Maori as Porohoe.
Notes:

Quote:  These rockers are massive structures of wood and iron, and rock in excavations made for the purpose. The rockers work backward and forward in sockets on the edges of their beds. Between each rocker is a strong beam; thus the whole line is connected, so that any motion imparted to one affects all the rockers.

Author:  NATUSCH
Vol / Page:  229
Edition:
Quote:  Family ACANTHOCLINIDAE (rockfishes). The rockfish <I>Acanthoclinus</I> ..., a long, straight fish with the tips of the dorsal fin running parallel to the back, and to the line of the anal and belly fin-tips, is common as a small fish of rock pools, where it hides under stones and seaweed; bigger ones occur in deeper water.

Date:  0/0/1970
Source:  Nomenclature of NZ Fish
Author:  SORENSON
Vol / Page:  19
Edition:
Quote:  DOGFISH, SPINY (a) Scientific name: <I>Squalus acanthias</I>. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Rockfish. (c) Other common names: Spiky dogfish, Spiny dogs, Southern dogfish, Spotted dogfish, Milky dogs. (d) Principal localities where taken: Largely restricted to cooler southern waters, ranging north to Hawke Bay in winter months. Plentiful off the Otago coast.

rockgas
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: compressed propane gas (LPG).
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Jim writes: Proprietary but (?) in wider use cf. Zip. No dictionary reference. DEH adds: In OED without citation : rock gas, natural gas obtained by boring through rock. Webster's 3rd refers one to "natural gas"  gas issuing from the earth's crust through natural openings or bored wells esp. any of various combustible gaseous mixtures that when in the dry state contain largely methane and in the wet state in association with petroleum contain also higher hydrocarbons ( as ethane, propane, butanes and pentanes)...

Citations
Date:  0/0/1986
Source:  Countless Signs
Author:  McNAUGHTON
Vol / Page:  132
Edition:
Quote:  "I use rock gas for the cooking and hot water"... They looked at the rock gas cylinder there. 'Rock Gas', it said on it, sure enough. <i>Ibid.</i> 136 He used one of the rock gas rings which never gave any trouble, and stood shivering as he waited for the jug to heat.
Notes:  From Owen Marshall (1982)  Body and Soul

rockling
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: fish
Citations
Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Austral English
Author:  MORRIS
Vol / Page:  392
Edition:
Quote:  <i> Rock-ling </i>, n. a marine fish. The Australian R. is <i> Genypterus australis </i> Cast1n., family <i> Ophidiida.</i> The European R. belongs to the genera <i> Onos </i> and <i> Rhinonemus </i>, formerly <i> Motella </i>. Of the genus <i> Genypterus </i>, Gunther says they have an excellent flesh, like cod, well adapted for curing. At the Cape they are known by the name of `Klipvisch,' and in New Zealand as <i> Ling </i>, or <i> Cloudy-Bay Cod. </i>

Rogernomics
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a label applied to the Lange Labour administration's policies of organisational and

economic reform, associated with the name of its first Finance Minister, the Hon. Roger Douglas.

Quote:  Take "Rogernomics". for instance. The term was born on February 23, 1985, as a headline on a <i>Listener</i> interview with Roger Douglas. The following week it was picked up by Bernard Lagan in the <i>Dominion</i> and went on from there to enter the language as a term for mad dog monetarism, Kiwi style.
Notes:

Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page:  83
Edition:

Date:  0/0/1989
Source:  Rogernomics
Author:  JAMES
Vol / Page:  1
Edition:
Quote:  At the heart of the discontent was "Rogernomics" - the popular word for the economic approach of Roger Douglas. Rogernomics deregulated where Muldoon had regulated, turned over to market forces those whom Muldoon had subsidised, cut taxes where Muldoon had raised them, subjected employers and unions to the painful wage discipline of controls on the money supply, exposed Muldoon's State departments to the market by turning trading operations into corporations, and requiring some other departments to earn part of their keep by selling their services.

Some of the roguing ... was done in the paddock before harvesting ...

Quote:  <I>Lophomyrtus obcordata</I> (Raoul) Burr. Maori name: <I>Rohutu</I> ... This shrub, and the closely allied <I>Neomyrtus pedunculata</I> (Hook.f.) Allan are found throughout New Zealand. Both are known as `rohutu', and it is possible that both were used for medicine. <I>Lophomyrtus obcordata</I> was known as <I>Myrtus obcordata</I> (Raoul) Hook.f. and <I>Neomyrtus pedunculata</I> was known as <I>Myrtus pedunculata</I> Hook.f.

Date:  0/0/1889

Vol / Page:  150
