Quote:  When growing at any considerable distance from a creek or river it is necessary to form rolling roads.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1953
Source:  Story of the Kauri, The
Author:  REED
Vol / Page:  172
Edition:
Quote:  An article in the Building World, 1889, had this to say: `Logging the Kauri in New Zealand is a rather exciting occupation - that is by the `rolling road' method of extraction ...'


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1894
Source:  NZ Official Yearbook
Author:
Vol / Page:  331
Edition:
Quote:  Flotation is the method most commonly used in the kauri districts ... After the trunks are cut into lengths a `rolling-road' is formed to the nearest creek. All the scrub is closely cut down for a width of from twenty-five to thirty feet ... to obtain an approximately even surface, inclined towards the creek. The logs are forced along this road by timber-jacks, which the bushmen use with remarkable skill, and are impelled with a rapidity which is simply astonishing to persons unused to the process. If the creek contains plenty of water the logs float to the nearest booms without further trouble ...
Notes:  (T. Kirk)

Date:  0/0/1953
Source:  Story of the Kauri, The
Author:  REED
Vol / Page:  170
Edition:
Quote:  Hochstetter in 1889 and Kirk in 1874 [Report to Parliament], refer to rolling roads. Kirk describes them as `broad tracks, thirty to forty feet wide, in which every advantage is taken of the natural incline of the surface, and from which all trees have to be removed, the stumps cut level with the surface, inequalities roughly levelled, and large holes filled up. The logs are forced along these roads by `timberjacks' until they reach the water. In this way the logs are moved with great ease. ...[D.H.McMillan] Rolling roads were formed by laying three rickers or other small trees lengthwise to the line of road, and logs were placed crosswise on this road. There might be thirty or forty or more in a fleet. Three men with timber lacks usually operated this job.


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1951
Source:  Radio NZ / National Radio
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  ... what was called the rolling road ... was anything up the 30 feet wide, with all the stumps cut down to ground level ... A lot of loose skids would probably be laid on the ground running in the direction the log would travel. The logs were then rolled along the road with jacks, usually two men to a log.


Notes:  [ca -1914] 1951 H.S. McCo[?a]rroll The Days of the Kauri Bushmen [Radio 4: TS]



Date:  0/0/1895

Author:
Vol / Page:  28/16
Edition:
Quote:  But before this [treefelling] has been done rolling-roads have been formed, or tramways laid, involving the vast destruction of arboreal growth ...

Source:  Folkgames of Children
Author:  SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page:  175
Edition:
Quote:  Some of the typical terms used in marbles referred to the act of shooting and the movement of the marbles. Those related to ways of shooting marbles were cribbing, firsts, fudging, funks, funnicks, funnigans, flunks, forces, knee-high, knuckle-down-stiff, knuckles, and lasts. Terms connected with the movement of the marbles were: cannons, clears, dead-stick, double-hits, fires, funs, gees, haystacks, in smug, keeps, kills, kisses, lay-ups, manyes, ones, pink, ringer, rolls, scat, screws, skinned, skun, spiders, sported-off, stays, stops, tracks, throughs.

roody doody
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: probably an early spg (as KOW-ROWDY-DOWDY) of Maori ruriruri, Williams 352 Ruri, ruriruri ... Song, ditty,  generally of an amorous nature, accompanied by gestures.: and  English dialect rowdy-rowdy.  kow- = ?Maori ko[o] sing; resound; a shout; or perhaps ko a particle.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: cf OED rowdy-dowdy `characterised by noisy roughness.' (1882); EDD Rowdy-dowdy: Sc. Ches. a merry-making.

Date:  0/0/1834
Source:  New Zealand (various authors/titles)
Author:  MARKHAM
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  The [Maori] will sit on a heap of Potatoes or log, and do what is called a Roody Doody. [a kind of gossiping, impromptu recitative, accompanied by rhythmic dancing etc, of all the happenings around them - scandals about the pas, obscene or lewd observations to discomfort the spectators etc. They will often keep it up for hours - on board ships, with traders or sailors. - and work up sexual passion]

rope

Sense Number:
Definition: specifically, the wire rope used to break logs out of the bush (cf ROPEY
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: ca 1950 R Gilberd Okaihau Letter A log can be hauled forward on `the rope', backwards on the `tail-rope' and the direction of pull can be varied by the use of a snatch block temporarily attached to a tree on one side or other of the log-way

Vol / Page:  13 : 71
Edition:
Quote:  There is a proverbial comparison for a woman's lips when well tattoed; such are said to resemble a rori (Paramphorus australis); the plump black smooth and glossy mantle of this shell-fish appearing, when living, its whole length on both sides from under its narrow back shell, and turning up and enveloping its sides, no doubt originated the proverb.

rosella
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a sheep which has cast or lost most of its wool


Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: (shearers')
Citations
Date:  28/10/1933
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  17
Edition:
Quote:  A sheep that has cast most of his wool before shearing,  so is very easy to shear. R. is a shearers' word, probably brought from Australia. [1898 Morris Austral-English] gives two meanings for the word but not this one: (1) a sort of parrot; (2) a European who works bare to the waist (North Australian slang). Our word is probably derived from (2). ([1898 Morris Austral-English])


Notes:  Acland Grossary

Date:  0/0/1940
Source:  Te Waimate
Author:  STUDHOLME
Vol / Page:  112
Edition:
Quote:  The `rosellas'; or easily shorn sheep ...
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1949
Source:  High Country Days
Author:  NEWTON
Vol / Page:  193
Edition:
Quote:  ROSELLA: A sheep which has lost the wool off its belly, i.e., torn off in matagouri or scrub. A sheep which has lost most of its wool is known as a `rosella.' ]


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1949
Source:  Dictionary of Slang Addenda
Author:  PARTRIDGE
Vol / Page:  1156
Edition:
Quote:  Rosella. 2. In Australia and New Zealand, since ca. 1910, it has  been sheep-shearing s. for `a sheep bare of wool on the `points' (hocks, head, foreleg, etc.) and consequently very easy to shear,' Niall Alexander, communucation of Oct. 22, 1939.


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1960
Source:  Back-Country Tales
Author:  MASTERS
Vol / Page:  257
Edition:
Quote:  My catching pen happened to be filled just on smoko time. In it I noticed right near the front, one rosella (sheep bare of wool except for a few tufts around the neck, and several others that appeared to be bare-bellies.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1989
Source:  NZ English Newsletter
Author:
Vol / Page:  3/21
Edition:
Quote:  bare belly: A sheep with defective wool growth caused by a break in the fibre structure. This causes the wool to fall off the belly and legs and is more common in ewes. These sheep are sometimes called `Rosellas'. <i>Ibid.</I> 3/27  (Wallace Shearing Glossary) rosella: A sheep with wool falling out of it.


Notes:  (Wallace Shearing Glossary)

Date:  0/0/1950
Source:  Farm & Station Verse
Author:  WOODHOUSE
Vol / Page:  49
Edition:
Quote:  We'd a bunch of Aussie shearers, and they come from New South Wales,/ They entertained the `rouseys' with a lot of fairy tales/ Of how they shore the jumbucks and rosellas from the hills,/


Notes:  c1900-1910 Goldstone `The Man From Kaiveroo' in 1950 Woodhouse Farm and Station Verse 49

rosella
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: a sheep that has no wool around the neck area or a sheep that is particularly easy to shear, with wool that  sloughs off.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1940
Source:  Te Waimate
Author:  STUDHOLME
Vol / Page:  129
Edition:
Quote:  When an old hand and a young one were sharing a catching pen, the former would let the learner in for the 'cobbler' or hard shearing sheep, at the end of every pen, and when the pen had been refilled, quickly catch and shear all the 'rosellas' or easily shorn sheep, before the unfortunate novice had finished his cobbler.
Notes:

rotaflow system

Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  8/5/1993
Source:  Dominion
Author:
Vol / Page:  17
Edition:
Quote:  I had long heard of the herring-bone

milking shed, but the rotaflow system..

was a new development... The Friesan cows

walk into individual bails on the slowly

revolving platform; the milking cups go

on; each cow does a circuit; the cups

are automatically removed; and then the

cows receive a light spray of water which

serves to nudge them out of the bail

towards the yard.

It took about an hour in a rotary shed that has more in common with the Sydney Opera House than with John Scott's old herringbone shed... One at a time, the cows boarded a huge, slow merry-go-round capable of holding 66 animals and stood side by side like slides in a carousel, heads facing the centre.

Notes:

rotation length
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: the length of time and rate of movement of stock around a farm.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1988
Source:  Agriculture in NZ
Author:  RENNIE
Vol / Page:  32
Edition:
Quote:  The length of term the herd of cows spend in each paddock is called the rotation length. In summer/autumn the farmer may again 'lengthen' the rotation by grazing cows in the same paddock for two milkings.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1999
Source:  NZ Pasture and Crop Science
Author:  WHITE ET AL
Vol / Page:  162
Edition:
Quote:  The definition of rotation length is often misunderstood. The common definition relates to the proportion of the farm being grazed in one day.  Rotation length describes the current rate of movement around the farm.
Notes:

Date:  26/7/2001
Source:  Taranaki Daily News
Author:
Vol / Page:  16
Edition:
Quote:  Remember that the farm area is fixed. It is critical not to reduce rotation length if you run out of feed.
Notes:

rotational cross

rotational grazing
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: the moving of a constant number of stock from paddock to paddock, in order to control feed.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations

Source:  Agricultural Organization in NZ
Author:
Vol / Page:  28
Edition:
Quote:  The more effective utilization of pastures is also facilitated by so-called `rotational grazing,' milking cows being followed in a field by dry and young stock or ewes.

Quote:  Rotational grazing was not much used by dairy farmers in the 1940s; the length of fencing seemed to many to make the idea uneconomic.

I have not been able to find anything yet to confirm this - unfortunately we have not indexed the Daily Post for the 1980s yet.

Citations
Date:  4/6/1999
Source:  Dominion
Author:
Vol / Page:  12
Edition:
Quote:  Even more of a nuisance to New Zealand farmers are Californian poppies, Escholzia californica, better known in Centra Otago in my childhood as rotten eggs. This was probably for the intense orange of the flowers... In its home in California, great sweeps of egg-yolk gold against the blue leaves are breathtaking. Since the rotten egg has become a darling of the landscape designer, several colours have evolved, including pink, a near brown, and a beautiful soft clotted-cream that comes true from seed year after year.

rough as a soojee bag
Homonym Number:
Word Class: phrase
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1939
Source:  First White Boy Born in Otago
Author:  BEATTIE
Vol / Page:  97
Edition:
Quote:   [Sugar] came in mats, the big ones weighing 180 lbs, and was often called `mat sugar'. This mat was native made, being a pleated plant, and was pretty well square. Outside this mat, and covering it, was a coarse bag called a soojee (or suji?) bag. A familiar saying of the early days was, `As rough as a soojee bag', and this saying was applied to both people and things. Up to 1863 I never saw sugar except in mats ...

rough gecko
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: widespread in the Marlborough region this gecko has enlarged scales over the upper surfaces of its body, unusual in a New Zealand lizard.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: <i>Naultinus rudis</i> aka rough scaled gecko, rough-scaled gecko. The other NZ lizard with pronounced scaliness is the Marlborough green, or manuka, gecko.

Citations
Date:  0/9/2010
Source:  NZ Geographic
Author:
Vol / Page:  50
Edition:
Quote:  Despite such constraints, a boldly patterned rough-scaled gecko appears almost invisible among manuka blossom (top left), even the textured scales assisting in the deception.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/2009
Source:  Internet - see Notes
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  The Rough Scaled or Rough Gecko is confined to the Kaikoura Ranges, on the east coast of New Zealand's South Island. They generally live in manuka and kanuka, known as tea tree and in forests also. Most active by day. Parts of the gecko are covered in rough scales giving rise to its name.


Notes:  Date is an estimate http://www.nhc.net.nz/index/lizards-new-zealand/rough-gecko/rough-gecko.htm

rough it
Homonym Number:
Word Class: verb
Sense Number:
Definition: and vbl n ROUGHING IT) `live a rough life; live on rough fare or in rough quarters' is very frequent from 1838 [get quot]. It is often italicised or used within quotation marks, indicating that many early writers considered it `colonial' usage

Rough Riders

Date:  0/0/1900

Vol / Page:  1

Quote:  [Title] To the New Zealand Rough-Riders (Title page and cover: The Rough Riders Contingent for South Africa)


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1907
Source:  New Zealanders & the Boer War
Author:  HAYDON
Vol / Page:  59
Edition:
Quote:  The third contingent, or Rough Riders.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1907
Source:  With the Fourth NZ Rough Riders
Author:  MOORE
Vol / Page:  10
Edition:
Quote:  It may not be amiss to explain how the name `Rough  Riders' came to be applied to the contingents. The Premier .... expressed a strong opinion that we should not accept the title of `Bushmen' which had been adopted in Australian. [because of possible confusion with the Bushmen of South Africa] .... As they were not regularly trained troops, and were to be good riders ready for rough work, he thought they should be called `Rough Riders', and expressed the hope that they would be particularly rough on the enemy. Accordingly the name was adopted, and under it the Third and Fourth Contingents have been raised.


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1949
Source:  Short History of Belfast, Canterbury
Author:  BROWN
Vol / Page:  12
Edition:
Quote:  The departure of a few lads to the Boer War at the turn of the century - Rough Riders they were called. ....

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1982
Source:  Heritage Trail
Author:  HARWOOD
Vol / Page:  64
Edition:
Quote:   [Boer War] At the start of the Boer War he enlisted in the 5th Contingent of `Rough Riders' The name `Rough Riders' was given to the New Zealand troops by thte[sic] Premier, the Right Hon. Richard John Seddon. He was of the opinion that they should not be called `Bushmen' as the Australian men were called. He had been told that the Bushmen of Africa were held in contempt and he objected to New Zealand men starting with a name that would suggest anything but the respects he was quite sure they would be entitled to.

rough sheep
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition:  a sheep that has missed a docking, shearing or muster and is often wild.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See: double-fleecer; double-decker; hermit; long tailer
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  23/1/1875
Source:  Otago Witness
Author:
Vol / Page:  18
Edition:
Quote:  The tobacco may be put in wire cages or gunny bags, and allowed to boil ten minutes, 400 gallons at once, in malt tanks, the lids being on; but the best plan is to infuse under pressure of steam from a boiler, a pipe from which would heat the dip in the morning and regulate the temperature afterwards, which with newly shorn sheep should be 115 to 118 deg., and in rough sheep 120 to 125 deg. About 1½ minutes for shorn and 2 for rough sheep should be effectual.
Notes:

Date:  3/12/1884
Source:  Wanganui Herald
Author:
Vol / Page:  3
Edition:
Quote:  CHALLENGE. THROUGH some ill-feeling against me at the Oroua Downs, I am willing to shear Mr. Jenkins, in long-wool sheep, for any sum from £5 to £20; but I do not call it fair shearing for another man to shear all the rough sheep out of his pen. JOSEPH MORRISON.
Notes:

Date:  27/2/1896
Source:  Otago Witness
Author:
Vol / Page:  26
Edition:
Quote:  In all 6,789 sheep, 25 head cattle, and 6 horses were sold as follows: .. 59 rough sheep at 9s 8d, 1117 crossbred lambs to 4s 11d.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1947
Source:  Wayleggo
Author:  NEWTON
Vol / Page:   [Gloss].
Edition:
Quote:  Rough Sheep: Domesticated sheep which has escaped musterers and has gone semi-wild. Distinct from the real wild sheep of  Canterbury, and unlike them do not shed their wool. Consequently they become overburdened with wool, which at times reached such length that it drags on the ground <I>Ibid.</i> Wayleggo 29  ... Catching stragglers and rough sheep. <I>Ibid.</I> 154  These sheep were real wild sheep - not the ordinary domestic sheep gone wild. The latter, long-tailers and woolies which have escaped muster and gone semi-wild, are known as `rough sheep'

roughing out
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: the using of machines with blades to clear land of large trees, leaving some debris behind in windrows.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1940
Source:  Cavalcade of Farming 1840-1940
Author:  FERRIS
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  The roughing-out work was done with either a bulldozer or treedozer. The treedozer had the advantage of leaving a windrow on either side of the blade as it passes through the ground surface in the roughing out operation. When the treedozer was used for roughing out, windrows were left throughout the paddock containing stumps, bush, debris and some soil.

Date:  28/5/1887
Source:  Auckland Weekly News
Author:
Vol / Page:  37
Edition:
Quote:  [Advt] R-r-rats! Rats! Rats! Rough on Rats!

Hang your dogs and drown your cats;

We give a plan for every man

To clear his house with Rough on Rats.

extensively advertised and has the

and Insect destroyer in the world. Sold

to all nations.

rough-riding
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1892
Source:  NZ Official Handbook
Author:
Vol / Page:  157
Edition:
Quote:  On a cattle-run the tasks of mustering and drafting the stock and branding the youngsters are very heavy work, needing the display of considerable powers of rough-riding among the horsemen; while on a sheep-run the lambing and shearing seasons tax every power of the station-hands.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  History of Children's Play
Author:  SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page:  112
Edition:
Quote:  Apart from simple climbing there was, for example, `crossing' the plantation on the treetops, and Rough-riding, in which one player sat on a fir tree branch while the others took the end of it and pulled it up and down and then let it go flying up in the air. The player who could stay on the longest was the rough-riding champion. Of a similar nature was Buck-jumping, in which individual players rode a macrocarpa or gum branch [113] to see who could rise the highest.

Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1982
Source:  Collins Guide
Author:  AYLING
Vol / Page:  174
Edition:  1984
Quote:  COMMON ROUGHY (Sandpaper fish) <i>Paratrachichthys  trailli</i> ... This species of roughy has small rough scales and because of this [175] feature it is sometimes known as the sandpaper fish. ... Common roughys are found throughout New Zealand, although they are rarely seen north of Cook Strait.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1939
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  69/231
Edition:
Quote:  Paratrachichthys trailli (Hutton). ... The Roughy or Sand-paper Fish, as the species is called, is not uncommon in trawler catches in New Zealand and southern Australia.

Date:  15/4/1911
Source:  NZ Truth
Author:
Vol / Page:  303/1/2
Edition:
Quote:   ... for in the Australiasian vernacular the person who `rousts' or `rouses' goes temporarily mad and yells, and is an irresponsible person while he is `rousting' or `rousing', and the condition so nearly approaches the mild insanity of the wowser in his neurotic outbursts of oratory that Churchill must be congratulated upon stumbling upon a great truth.

Notes:

rouseabout
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition:  a general farm hand, who does many different duties.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  2/12/1882
Source:  Waikato Times
Author:
Vol / Page:  2
Edition:
Quote:  Their mode of living is on the strict hand-to-mouth principle; the future is a disagreeable prospect, which they endeavour to ignore, content if the present affords them a fair modicum of enjoyment; big cheques are earned, but they are melted with much greater celerity; and so the round of life goes on from year to year, until old age finds them still on the wallaby, burdened with aches and pains, unfitted for the only work of which they know anything, and glad to accept the billet of a farm yard "rouseabout," or "wood and water Joey."
Notes:

Date:  5/2/1891
Source:  North Otago Times
Author:
Vol / Page:  3
Edition:
Quote:  And now for the rouse abouts. Their case is not the best in the world. They, like the shearers, have to put up with bad food and bad accomodation, and like musterers they complain of not being paid in proportion to the work they do. The rouseabout has to work ten hours a day, and nine or thereabouts on Saturdays.

Vol / Page:  31
Edition:
Quote:  A rouseabout - also variously known as a rousie, woolhandler, shedhand, fleeco, the person `picking up' or a blue tongue - is responsible for the passage of wool after being shorn from the sheep's back to the wool press where it is baled. <I>Ibid.</I> 33  A rousie, or wool winder as they're called in England, would at least pay for half a return ticket from New Zealand in the two-month season there.

roust
Homonym Number:
Word Class: verb
Sense Number:
Definition: to stir up, scold
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: ca1900 He rousted them up for getting drunk  cf P. rouse 2. pron [raus] to grouse, scold esp. if coarsely: Aust: 20c. 3. upbraid with many words: Aust:20; AC 1900-1910.

royal albatross
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: royal albatross. D. epomophora, a huge black and white seabird breeding exclusively in the NZ region; of two races:  northern and southern royal albatross. <i>D. e. sanfordi</i>, breeding on the Chatham Islands and Otago Peninsula, and southern <i>D. e. epomophora</i>, breeding on subantarctic islands.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Environment
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  7/2/1900
Source:  Star, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  3
Edition:
Quote:  While on a recent cruise, Commander Ayscough, of H.M.S. Ringdove, collected specimens of a number of birds, which he presented to the Christchurch Museum. These have now been placed on exhibition in the New Zealand room, and include a Royal albatross from Campbell Island, a pair of woodhens from Stewart Island, a paroquet and a ground lark from the Antipodes Islands, and a bush hawk from the Auckland Islands.
Notes:

Date:  1/7/1911
Source:  Evening Post
Author:
Vol / Page:  9
Edition:
Quote:  The Buller collection of butterflies and several cases of butterflies from the islands adjacent to New Guinea are now on view at the Museum. The new case of birds, which is now only wanting labels, comprises, amongst other things, an adult Royal albatross, two stages of the young in down of the wandering albatross, also a specimen of the shy albatross, and two or three others of the rarer kind.
Notes:

Date:  21/9/1938
Source:  Auckland Weekly News

Vol / Page:  20

Quote:  The arrival at the heads last year of ten Royal Albatross was regarded as an event of the first importance in local scientific circles.

Roys Peak gecko
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a rare and brightly spotted gecko from Otago highlands.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: <i>Hoplodactylus "Roys Peak"</i> aka Orange-spotted gecko

Citations
Date:  0/0/2001
Source:  Internet - see Notes
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  The data collected during the three surveys of Roys Peak and outlined in this

report provide only limited data on distribution. However, it appears Roys

Peak geckos are an alpine gecko, as all specimens were found above 1000 m,

and below this altitude common geckos <i>Hoplodactylus ` Southern Alps'</i>

(Hitchmough 1997) were numerous.


Notes:  http://www.doc.govt.nz/upload/documents/science-and-technical/casn344.pdf 2001 Tocher, M.D.; Marshall, LJ, 2001. Surveys for <i>Hoplodactylus</i> aff. <i>granulatus</i>, Roys Peak and Mt Alpha, Wanaka.

Source:  Internet - see Notes
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:

national significance. This species has a threat status of Nationally Critical (Hitchmough,

2002).

rua

Sense Number:

Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:

Vol / Page:  35/21
Edition:
Quote:   ... the object was very simply attained in the dry  porous soil by the rua. This was a circular pit sunk in the ground 5 ft. or 6 ft. deep and about the same in diameter, narrowing in at the top and closed by a trap-door made of a wooden slab.

Vol / Page:  1/34

Quote:
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1952
Source:  Faring South
Author:  LYON
Vol / Page:  158
Edition:
Quote:  Their chief quest was a pot hole which might be described as much like a Maori rua or potato pit. A soft seam of rock played on by the tumbling waters and some stones always on the grind and move, wore down and sideways till the top was smaller than the bottom and an arched roof was the result, and a small opening at the top received through the ages particles of gold. The heavy swirl and pressure of water was unable to twist the gold contents out of the pot hole, and so a store of gold collected in the bottom and might contain nuggets as well as dust.


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1966

Quote:  Replicas of ancient pataka, (carved food storage house), kauta (shelter for food preparation) and rua kumara (carved kumara storage pit) will be built using traditional Maori stone tools.

rub noses
Homonym Number:
Word Class: phrase
Sense Number:
Definition: to hongi
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: a long-used descriptive Pakeha misconception of the Maori HONGI `salute by pressing the noses together; incorrectly called rub noses.' (Williams)
Citations
Date:  0/0/1819
Source:  Letters & Journals
Author:  MARSDEN
Vol / Page:  187
Edition:  1932

Date:  0/0/1845
Source:  Voyage of the Beagle
Author:  DARWIN
Vol / Page:  Ch.XVIII (Everyman edn) 407
Edition:  1860
Quote:  On coming near one of the huts I was much amused by seeing in due form the ceremony of rubbing, or, as it ought to be called, pressing noses. The women, on our first approach, began uttering something in a most dolorous voice, they then squatted themselves down and held up their faces; my companion standing over them, one after another, placed the bridge of his nose at right angles to theirs, and commenced pressing.
Notes:  1835 Dec 23 in 1845 (1860) Darwin Voyage of Beagle

Date:  0/0/1984
Source:  Witi Ihimaera
Author:  CORBALLIS & GARRETT
Vol / Page:  23
Edition:
Quote:  Further changes were made before the first `Tangi' (in Contemporary Maori Writing) became

the definitive version (in Pounamu, Pounamu). ... The characters `rub' noses in the earlier version; they `press' them in the later one. ... [24] Finally, in three passages (pp. 126, 130) - but not in a fourth (p. 128) - the `pa' becomes a `meeting house'. ... (`Pa' tends to have pejorative associations in Pakeha parlance, ...)

Hereafter I will explain why at such meetings the natives do not jump up and say how glad they are to see you, but welcome you in woe-begone `Haere mai's', squatting down and rubbing the lugubrious nose until the spectacle is anything but pleasant to look at.

Notes:

run
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: grazing land
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: also cattle run, sheep run
Pronunciation:
Notes: also cattle run, sheep run 		Acland distinguished six uses of the noun, because of change or extension of the meaning of the original borrowing; run off, (Farming) land which is not part of a developed farm but which is used for intermittent grazing.
Citations
Date:  23/4/1864
Source:  Otago Witness
Author:
Vol / Page:  12
Edition:
Quote:  FOR SALE, a Small Farm, part of which is heavily timbered, convenient to a shipping place, with plenty of water, and a good run for cattle.
Notes:

Date:  18/11/1933
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  15
Edition:
Quote:  Run.- The pioneers of sheep farming in New Zealand and Australia came from various classes; but there were few among them who had been sheep farmers before and fewer still who were scientists. If they had been sheep farmers they would probably have used the English or Scotch sheep farming words (as they did to some extent) and fitted them to the new conditions. If they had been scientists they would have invented exact names for everything new, and translated them into Latin. What they did do was to take the handiest word they could think of and give it a new meaning, As time went on the word they had chosen changed or extended its meaning. The best example of all  this is the word run.
Notes:  >Acland's senses 1 and 5 seem to be the central ones, with the others being specialisations of, or obvious inferences from those. -->cf also Morris



Date:  15/11/1933
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  15
Edition:
Quote:  [Cont] (1) The country held under a particular lease or pastoral license. [sic] (PAUL, p. 92)  (2) Group of rs. held by one owner, or in one station. The  whole area is spoken of as a r. (C.RH., p. 90) (3) Leasehold as opposed to freehold. (Sheep returns, 1878)  (4) Open as opposed to fenced country. `Out on the r.'; i.e., not in any of the paddocks. ([1874 Lady Barker Station Life], p. 62)  (5) Adjective. R. sheep, r. cattle, as opposed to paddock sheep or milking cows and hand-reared calves. (C.)  (6) As equivalent to station: e.g. `He has sold his r.';  `One of the best rs. in Canterbury.' In this sense r. did  not always include the sheep, as the word s[tation].  does. This usage is now uncommon and r. in these contexts would probably mean small grazing r. ([1874 Kennaway Crusts], p. 86;Butler A First Year in Canterbury Settlement],p. 152)  (7) A block of country, a division of a r. E.g. ewe r.  upper r. This sense was always rare, but is still in use  on some ss. ([1898 Morris Austral-English]) (8) To keep or carry. `He runs merinos'; `the station runs 10,000 sheep' ([1898 Morris Austral-English]; C)


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Austral English
Author:  MORRIS
Vol / Page:  397
Edition:
Quote:  Run, n. (1) Tract of land over which sheep or cattle may graze.  It is curious that what in England is called a sheep-walk, in Australia is a sheep-run. In the Western United States it is a sheep -ranch. Originally the squatter, or sheep-farmer, did not own the land. It was unfenced, and he simply had the right of grazing or `running' his sheep or cattle on it. Subsequently, in many cases, he purchased the freehold, and the word is now applied to a large station- property, fenced or unfenced. (See quotation, 1883.) [1826]


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1966
Source:  English Language in Aust. & NZ, The
Author:  TURNER
Vol / Page:  50
Edition:
Quote:  First a run is a parcel of land as leased. A sheepfarmer might own several adjacent runs of land, in this sense, and the whole `station' so formed might also be termed a  run. In the third sense a  run was leasehold as opposed to freehold land; in a fourth sense, open land as opposed to fenced land. It might be used as an adjective, e.g. run cattle. It might be the equivalent of  station but without including the sheep, i.e. `He sold his run' need not imply that he sold his sheep, but `He sold his station' would.


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1989
Source:  NZ English Newsletter
Author:
Vol / Page:  3/27
Edition:
Quote:  run: [1] This word has several uses but the most common refers to a stretch of work. The official shearing time of two hours is called a `run'. The day is divided into four of these. 7.30am-9.30am, smoke-o; 10.00am-12 noon, dinner; 1.00pm-3.00pm smoke-o; 3.30pm-5.30pm, tea.  [2] Also another name for a sheep station.  [3] Also the contract circuit. A shearing contractor will arrange a `run' of sheds for his gang each season.


Notes:  (Wallace Shearing Glossary)

Vol / Page:  3
Edition:
Quote:  It is bounded by the Western Coast where there is some good Land, and dry run for Sheep.

Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Contributions to the Early History of New Zealand
Author:  HOCKEN
Vol / Page:  138
Edition:
Quote:  Under the original terms, land purchasers were entitled upon payment of an annual license fee of 10s. 6d. to depasture or  run sheep and cattle upon such waste lands within the block as remained unappropriated. ... though Captain Cargill was then gazetted Commissioner of Crown Lands for the Otago block only, he received no definite instructions upon the subject of granting the runs. [139] The result was that he merely filed the applications for depasturage licenses as they were presented to him, whilst the applicants were left to pursue their further course as seemed best to them.

run cray

Sense Number:

Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  Fisherman's Bible
Author:  WILSON
Vol / Page:  41
Edition:
Quote:   Fishermen often use the term `run crayfish' for light-coloured crayfish, with yellow being a more prominent colour than usual. These runcrays are either males or juvenile females, and they are usually potted on the outer edges of the rough bottom where it merges into sand, or on light rough bottom where the rock outcrops are small.

run the cutter
Homonym Number:
Word Class: phrase
Sense Number:
Definition: to procure beer in a vessel (poss. orig. on the sly) for drinking off the licensed premises, often after hours.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  22/12/1906
Source:  NZ Truth
Author:
Vol / Page:  79/5/8
Edition:
Quote:  `He runs the cutter between a brothel in Frederick-Street and a nearby hotel', remarked Tec. Cassells of a crook in the S.M.'s court during the week. `Running the cutter' is a variant of the Sydney expression `running the rabbit' and the Yankee ones of `rushing the growler' or `the can' Which all mean the same thing i.e. fetching beer in a vessel.
Notes:

Date:  0/8/1933
Source:  Oreti Anthology, The

Vol / Page:  12

Author:  BIDDY PURCELL
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  . `Pat [her husband] used to run the cutter when he was at St. Pats College in the 1930s' [= bring in illicit booze]
Notes:  ca1972 Oct 5 Havelock Biddy Purcell, publican's wife

Date:  0/0/1962
Source:  Horse
Author:  BAXTER
Vol / Page:  20
Edition:  1958
Quote:  And Horse had run the cutter down to the pub to bring back three gallon jars of beer.
Notes:  c1962 Baxter Horse (1985) (Mills of God) 20

Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  Black Billy Tea
Author:  CHARLES67
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  The expression `running the cutter' has its origins in the whaling days. ... `Grog shops' sprang up wherever ships called regularly ... When a ship lay at anchor, most of the crew would go ashore and an `anchor watch' would be left aboard. Very often, some thirsty soul ... would `borrow' the cutter and slip ashore for rum ... This was `running the cutter'. Later, in days when some areas were under prohibition, the term was used for the job of going to the nearest licensed hotel for liquor. ... And the driver comes in and breasts up to the bar./ He says, `Give me a jar and a couple of crates,/ For I am running the cutter tonight for me mates!'/... `We are fresh out of beer,/So that's why I'm here,/ Running the cutter tonight./

He [Mr. Rogan] remarks that at this time the Maories first adopted the term `runanga,' the term `komiti' having previously been used by them in respect to deliberative meetings.

Maori runanga (assemblies) in the various districts were to recommend to the Governor the laws they required. He could introduce them by Order-in-Council without seeking parliamentary assent. <I>Ibid.,</I> 302  [Maori glossary] runanga Assembly

Quote:  There is the ...runholder and more important station owner; there is the cow cocky, the gold miner ... the Public Works raceman ...
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1947
Source:  Early Runholding in Otago
Author:  BEATTIE
Vol / Page:  10
Edition:
Quote:  [In 1851 a number of Australian `squatters' came over and took up runholding] Over here [in Canterbury the Australian `squatters'] were called runholders. ... [11] see SHEEPMEN... [11]

When I first read this inscription [in the Memorial Church, Cave], the word `sheep-men' made me involuntarily flinch. Years later, when I had forgotten it, I suddenly met it again, and again I recoiled. So aghast was I that I spent weeks collecting every old term for `runholders' I could, and I found thirteen, viz., `flock owners,' `flock masters,' `pastoralists,' `run holders,' `run owners,' `sheep owners,' `sheep holders,' `sheep masters,' `squatters,' `station holders,' `station owners,' `stock holders,[sic] and `stock owners.' The word `sheepmen' is a modern Americanism, and using this anachronism mars a splendid memorial. ... [12] Of all the thirteen terms found in old documents, the word `runholder' was the most used, and it is the word that I think should be substituted.


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1948
Source:  Our Own Country
Author:
Vol / Page:  135
Edition:

Edition:
Quote:  The words flew, and enriched Celia's [an English visitor's] vocabulary. `Duck shoving' was the local name for buck-passing between government departments. A `Queen Street farmer' was a city slicker who owned land or stock for tax-fiddle reasons. `Skite' and `drongo' were terms of abuse. A `cow-cockie' was a dairy farmer and inferior for some reason to a `runholder' concerned only with sheep. A `piker' was a faint-hearted person who gave up the fight too soon, ...

Quote:  From certain intestines sausage casings are prepared, and in 1887 Henry Berry & Co. contracted to purchase ... clean `runners', after which various firms carried on the business of doing the finishing for market. <i>Ibid.</I> 72 An important by-product is sausage casings, which are made from several parts of the gut, the main source being the very long small intestine of the sheep. This, in the untreated state, is called a `runner'.

Date:  0/0/1947
Source:  Early Runholding in Otago
Author:  BEATTIE
Vol / Page:  11
Edition:
Quote:  When I first read this inscription [in the Memorial Church, Cave], the word `sheep-men' made me involuntarily flinch. Years later, when I had forgotten it, I suddenly met it again, and again I recoiled. So aghast was I that I spent weeks collecting every old term for `runholders' I could, and I found thirteen, viz., `flock owners,' `flock masters,' `pastoralists,' `run holders,' `run owners,' `sheep owners,' `sheep holders,' `sheep masters,' `squatters,' `station holders,' `station owners,' `stock holders,[sic] and `stock owners.'  The word `sheepmen' is a modern Americanism, and using this anachronism mars a splendid memorial. ... [12] Of all the thirteen terms found in old documents, the word `runholder' was the most used, and it is the word that I think should be substituted.
Notes:

Date:  10/6/1907

Russian scare
Homonym Number:

Sense Number:
Definition: the threat of coastal invasion of New Zealand during the 1870s and 1880s

Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]

Vol / Page:  49
Edition:
Quote:  Around the early 1870s the so called "Russian scare", that is the threat of invasion to New Zealand from the sea, the Boroughs of Hokitika, Greymouth and Westport raised concerns to Government, which led to one of each of these cannons being despatched as a means of defence of the coast and river mouths.

Date:  0/4/1935
Source:  NZ Inst. Arch. Journal
Author:
Vol / Page:  20
Edition:
Quote:  At the same time (c 1870s) the rusticated weatherboard made its appearance - the invention of it being attributed to Toxwood, who was an artichtect [sic] trained in Denmark. . .  In the days of the wooden rusticated house.. the wealth of the fortunate owner was  reflected in the character and elaboration of the external adornment. <i>Ibid.</i> 21 The plain rusticated wall with stops was the lowest degree; if quoins were mitred at the corners that was an indication of greater refinement; but for the highest type and the wealthier client the quoins must be ovolo molded.


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1988
Source:  Buildings of Dunedin

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1991
Source:  NZ Architecture
Author:  SHAW
Vol / Page:  24
Edition:
Quote:  A Greek survival building faced with Tasmanian sandstone, the facade has a rusticated ground floor with attached fluted Doric columns supporting an entablature and cornice.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1986
Source:  Old New Zealand Houses
Author:  SALMOND
Vol / Page:  114
Edition:
Quote:  Another kind of weatherboard which became popular in the 1880‘s was the "rusticated" board, where the top edge was planed down to fit behind a rebate in the edge of the next board. The completed wall showed pronounced grooves which resembled channel-jointed stonework, and in more elaborate houses timber <i>quoins</i> at corners assisted the illusion. The introduction of the rusticated board has been attributed to the Wellington architect Julius Toxward in the 1860s.


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1982
Source:  Collins Concise English Dictionary
Author:
Vol / Page:  1013
Edition:
Quote:  rusticated or rusticating n. (in New Zealand) a wide type of weatherboarding used in older houses.


Notes:  [nf. 1986 NZPOD; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 427]

Source:  West Coast Gold Rushes
Author:  MAY
Vol / Page:  238
Edition:  1962
Quote:  The mercury plates were seldom perfect: the finest gold was lost by flotation while with cemented gold a thin coating of iron oxide (`rusty gold') often prevented amalgamation. The mercury itself became `sick' or `floured'; both sodium and nitric acid were employed to improve its amalgamating qualities.
